Ward, Randy K., Clinical Assistant Professor II of Family Medicine and Clinical Instructor in Psychiatry,
Medical School, April 15, 2000 (previously reported as March 31, 2000)
CANCELLATION OF REGENTS COMMUNICATION
Florida, Nancy K., appointed to Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies Executive Board,
September 1, 2000-August 31, 2003, vice David J. Brophy, term expired
Retirement Memoirs. Vice President Tedesco submitted memoirs for ten faculty
members.
Yuri Gurevich, Ph.D., professor of electrical engineering and computer science in
the College of Engineering, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 2000.
A native of the former Soviet Union, Professor Gurevich received his M.Sc. degree
from Ural University in 1962 and his Ph.D. degree from Novosibirsk University in
1964; he also received a doctorate degree in 1968. In the USSR, he served on the
faculty of Ural University, the Institute for National Economics, and Kuban University
before emigrating to Israel in 1973. In Israel, he served on the faculty of Ben-Gurion
University. He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan in 1982 as professor of
computer and communication sciences.
Professor Gurevich' s research in logic and theoretical computer science is
internationally recognized, as evidenced by invitations to lecture all over the world. As
a mathematician, he obtained fundamental results in mathematical logic. In theoretical
computer science, he strives to link his work to real-world applications. For example,
his work in dynamic structures uncovered ambiguities in specifications for real
programming language.      He has made significant contributions to computational


88




September Meeting, 2000


complexity theory and has become one of the leaders in the effort to develop a theory of
average-case complexity. Professor Gurevich also has been instrumental in developing
theoretical computer science at the University of Michigan, and he is responsible for the
present structure of the graduate curriculum in this area. His former graduate students
have gone on to academic posts both here and abroad and to positions in industry.
Professor Gurevich is a fellow of the Association for Computing. He received the
Distinguished Visitor Medal from the University of Helsinki in 1995 and received an
honorary degree from the University of Limburg, Belgium in 1998. He received the
University's Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award in 1990 and the Faculty
Recognition Award in 1995.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his distinguished contributions by
naming Yuri Gurevich professor emeritus of electrical engineering and computer
science.
Ira Konigsberg, Ph.D., professor of English language and literature and professor
of film and video studies in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired from
active faculty status on May 31, 2000.
Professor Konigsberg earned his B.A. degree from City College of New York in
1956, his M.A. degree from Columbia University in 1957, and his Ph.D. degree from
Stanford University in 1961. He joined the University of Michigan as an associate
professor of English in 1968 and was promoted to professor in 1974. Professor
Konigsberg was named professor of English and film and video studies in 1988 and
served as director of the Program in Film and Video Studies from 1988-95. He was
named professor of film and video studies in 1995.
Professor Konigsberg began his career as a specialist in eighteenth century literature
and the history of the novel and then expanded his range to include critical theory and
world film. He made his reputation with two early books, Samuel Richardson and the
Dramatic Novel (1968) and Narrative Technique in the English Novel: Defoe to Austen
(1985). American Criticism in the Poststructuralist Age (1981) signaled his growing
interest in critical theory. That emphasis informed his expansion into film and video
studies, where he is best known for his standard reference work The Complete Film
Dictionary (1987, revised 1997), and for a more recent book, The Movies: Texts,
Receptions, and Exposures, which he co-edited for the University of Michigan Press
(1996). Throughout his publications, Professor Konigsberg displayed wide learning,
theoretical awareness, and a sly wit, as evidenced by the title of his chapter in the book,
Retakes on Remakes (1998): "How Many Draculas Does It Take to Change a Light
Bulb?"
During his tenure as director of the Program in Film and Video Studies, Professor
Konigsberg built the faculty and course structure to make it a national presence. His
courses in film, like those in English, often attracted large numbers of students.
Undergraduate and graduate students sought him out, and he served on numerous
examination and dissertation committees in both fields. In recognition of his pedagogic
skills, he received awards stretching chronologically from a Fulbright Lectureship on
American Literature at the University of Vienna in 1966-67 to the Excellence in
Education Award of the University of Michigan in 1998.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Ira Konigsberg professor
emeritus of English language and literature and professor emeritus of film and video
studies.


89




September Meeting, 2000


Naomi Lohr, Ph.D., assistant professor of psychology, Department of Psychiatry,
retired from active faculty status on June 30, 2000, after a most productive and
influential career.
Professor Lohr received her A.B. degree from Cornell University in 1957 and her
M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1959 and 1967,
respectively. She served internships at the Veteran's Administration Regional Office in
Detroit, Michigan, and with the University of Michigan Counseling Division and
Psychological Clinic. She also completed postgraduate training at Wolverine State
Group Psychotherapy Society in Detroit.
Professor Lohr joined the University of Michigan as a lecturer in 1963 and was
promoted to assistant professor in 1971.  She served as director of postdoctoral
fellowship training in clinical psychobiology from 1981-83 and she was associate chair,
clinical area, Department of Psychology, from 1986-91. She was associate director for
the Personality Disorders Program from 1987-99, and her research group was one of the
first to uncover the correlation between sexual and other forms of abuse and borderline
personality disorder. For more than three decades, Professor Lohr was also closely
involved in the clinical supervision of undergraduate students, psychology interns, and
fellows and psychiatric residents. She was a member of numerous clinical psychology
dissertation committees.
Professor Lohr was a devoted teacher, mentor, and clinician. Throughout her
career, she has contributed substantial hours to the administrative and clinical needs of
the Departments of Psychiatry and Psychology. Faculty and staff have recognized her
wisdom, expertise, longevity, and devotion to the department and to its students and
trainees.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for her devoted service by
naming Naomi Lohr assistant professor emerita of psychology.
Gordon M. MacAlpine, Ph.D., professor of astronomy in the College of
Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on May 31,
2000.
A native of Montana, Professor Alpine received his B.A. degree from Earlham
College in 1967 and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Wisconsin at Madison in
1971. In 1971-72, he was a member of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton,
New Jersey. He joined the University of Michigan faculty as an assistant professor in
1972 and was promoted to associate professor in 1978 and professor in 1984.
Professor MacAlpine's early research centered on the application of atomic physics
to the interpretation of spectra of gaseous nebulae near hot stars and in active galactic
nuclei. His numerical photoionization code led to a better understanding of the
geometrical, physical, and chemical properties of the hot gas in AGN and in quasars.
He has also led the effort to better understand the dynamics and chemical composition
of the Crab Nebula, which has improved our understanding of the interaction of a
supernova remnant with the surrounding medium. At Michigan, he led a spectroscopic
survey program which discovered a variety of active galaxies and quasars, which
provided a more comprehensive sample of these objects than was available at that time.
In addition to his research activities, Professor MacAlpine was a highly effective
and well-loved teacher, noted for lucid explanations and concern for his students. He
taught advanced graduate courses and also reached a significant fraction of University
students through his large undergraduate class.


90




September Meeting, 2000


The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and scholar by naming Gordon
M. MacAlpine professor emeritus of astronomy.
Gerald A. O'Connor, M.D., associate professor of surgery, Medical School,
retired from active faculty status on June 30, 2000, following a productive career as a
clinician and teacher.
Dr. O'Connor received his B.S. degree from Loras College, Dubuque, Iowa, in
1949 and his M.D. degree from Creighton University, Omaha, Nebraska, in 1953. He
completed his internship and residency at the University of Michigan and then went into
private practice at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital. Dr. O'Connor joined the University of
Michigan faculty as a clinical instructor of surgery in 1958 and began to develop a
practice specializing in sports medicine. He was promoted to clinical assistant professor
in 1964 and clinical associate professor in 1980.
Dr. O'Connor has been the team physician for the University of Michigan Athletic
Department since 1964. The program he developed with Dr. Robert Anderson for the
delivery of health care to student-athletes has been adopted by many institutions
throughout the United States.
In 1984, Dr. O'Connor was named associate professor of surgery and medical
director of MedSport at Domino's Farms. Under his direction, MedSport has grown
into an important clinical center with 5 orthopaedists, 18,000 annual outpatient visits,
and 67,000 annual physical therapy visits.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his dedicated service
by naming Gerald A. O'Connor associate professor emeritus of surgery.
Daniel H. Ringler, D.V.M., professor of laboratory animal medicine and director of
the Unit for Laboratory Animal Medicine, retired from active faculty status on June 30,
2000.
A native of Ohio, Dr. Ringler earned his D.V.M. degree from the Ohio State
University in 1965 and served in the U.S. Army Veterinary Corps from 1965-67. From
1967-69, he undertook residency training in laboratory animal medicine at the
University of Michigan and also earned his M.S. degree in pathology from the
University of Michigan Medical School. He joined the faculty as an instructor of
laboratory animal medicine in 1969 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1971,
associate professor in 1975, and professor in 1979. He has served as director of the Unit
for Laboratory Animal Medicine since 1985.
Dr. Ringler is recognized internationally as a leader in the field of laboratory animal
science and medicine. During his tenure he has trained over 60 postdoctoral veterinary
fellows, most of whom are board certified by the American College of Laboratory
Animal Medicine. He has represented the University many times regarding the use of
animals in biomedical research, always giving thoughtful and insightful commentary
and bringing distinction upon himself, the University, and the professions of biomedical
research and laboratory animal medicine.  In 1991, he received a certificate in
recognition of exemplary service to the University of Michigan which reads, "Your
expertise, leadership, vision, and professionalism, as well as the enthusiasm with which
you approach your work, serve as an inspiration to the entire University community."
Dr. Ringler has received numerous awards for his teaching and leadership,
including the Charles A. Griffin Award of the American Association for Laboratory
Animal Science (AALAS), the association's highest award, in 1981. In 1998, he was
granted the Distinguished Alumnus Award from the College of Veterinary Medicine at


91




September Meeting, 2000


the Ohio State University. In the summer of 2000, he received the annual Charles River
Prize, the highest award given to laboratory animal veterinarians from the American
Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA).
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Daniel H.
Ringler professor emeritus of laboratory animal medicine.
William R. Solomon, M.D., professor of internal medicine, will retire from active
faculty status on September 30, 2000, after a productive career as a physician, teacher,
and researcher.
A native of New York, Dr. Solomon received his A.B. degree at Columbia College
in 1951 and his M.D. degree at New York University in 1955. Following an internship
at Western Reserve University from 1955-56, he went to the University of Michigan for
his residency training from 1956-59. He was a fellow in allergy from 1961-63 and
received his M.S. degree in internal medicine in 1964. He joined the University of
Michigan faculty as an instructor of internal medicine in 1963 and was promoted to
assistant professor in 1966, associate professor in 1969, and professor in 1976. From
1983-93 he served as chief of the Allergy Division in the Department of Internal
Medicine.
Dr. Solomon's interest in documenting training quality led him to help develop and
launch the "in-training examination" series for fellows in allergy and immunology. His
Recent work focused on the identification, through field collections and study of
herbarium materials, of a group of spores that remain "unknowns" despite their
abundance locally. Dr. Solomon helped develop and implement a study of allergic
asthma among inner city youngsters, including its potential for amelioration by practical
allergen avoidance measures. He has also worked to develop a network of bioaerosol
collection stations in Latin America in cooperation with interested allergists in
population centers. He has served as a consultant to numerous organizations, was a
visiting professor at many major universities, and served on the editorial boards of
several scientific publications.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physician, scholar, and educator for his
dedicated service by naming William R. Solomon professor emeritus of internal
medicine.
James Stewart-Robinson, Ph.D., professor of Turkish studies, Department of Near
Eastern Studies, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 2000, after 44 years of
distinguished service.
Born March 3, 1928, in Edinburgh, Scotland, Professor Stewart-Robinson received
his primary and secondary education in Turkey. He received his M.A. degree from the
University of Edinburgh in 1954 and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Edinburgh in
1959. The title of his dissertation was: "The Ottoman Biographies of Poets." He started
his career at the University of Michigan as an instructor in the Department of Near Eastern
Studies in 1956; was promoted to assistant professor in 1960, an associate professor in
1965, and to professor of Turkish studies in 1970. He was the director of Asian studies at
the University of Michigan from January 1963 through June 1965. He was acting director
of the Center for Middle Eastern and North African Studies from 1982-83.
Professor Stewart-Robinson has dedicated his scholarly career to the study of
Ottoman and Turkish language, literature, history, and culture. His publications on these


92




September Meeting, 2000


subjects, which demonstrate both his vast philological erudition and unique analytical
skills, have long become standard references for his fellow Turkologists both in the West
and in Turkey. Professor Stewart-Robinson's expertise is truly amazing. It spans the long
historical period from the rise of Turkish literature and polity in the eleventh and twelfth
centuries up to the formation of the Turkish Republic in the second decade of the
twentieth century. He has also taken acute interest in the literary and cultural life of
modem Turkey and followed closely recent political developments in that country.
Professor Stewart-Robinson has taught an extraordinary amount of courses at the
University of Michigan. He was always responsive to students' needs and readily
accommodated their requests for independent reading courses in addition to his busy work
load. Thus it was not infrequent for him to teach four or even five graduate and
undergraduate courses per term. Additionally, Professor Stewart-Robinson took active part
in a number of team-taught courses and coordinated a popular undergraduate survey course
on the history of Near Eastern literatures that covered a period of almost 4000 years. While
the total number of graduate and undergraduate students who studied with Professor
Stewart-Robinson was never high, the amount of time he invested in them held no upper
limit.
Through his scholarly and teaching career and his dedication to his profession,
Professor Stewart-Robinson has enriched the University and the international community
of Turkish studies scholars in which he has been, and in which he will continue to be, a
distinguished member.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated service
by naming James Stewart-Robinson professor emeritus of Turkish studies.
Leroy B. Townsend, Ph.D., Albert B. Prescott Professor of Medicinal Chemistry
in the College of Pharmacy and professor of chemistry in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 2000, after 21
years of service.
Professor Townsend received his B.S. and M.S. degrees from New Mexico
Highlands University in 1955 and 1957, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from
Arizona State University in 1965. He began his career as a faculty member at the
University of Utah in 1965 and joined the University of Michigan in 1979 as professor
of medicinal chemistry in the College of Pharmacy; professor of chemistry in the
College of Literature, Science, and the Arts; and chair and program director of the
Interdepartmental Graduate Program in Medicinal Chemistry. He was named the Albert
B. Prescott Professor of Medicinal Chemistry in 1986.
A world-renowned scientist, Professor Townsend has been honored and highly
acclaimed for his work in the design and synthesis of heterocyclic compounds as
potential agents to treat cancer and infectious diseases. He is a pioneer in the synthesis
of several nucleoside antibiotics, including the first in a new class of compounds,
C-nucleoside antibiotics. He has been commended for his work in developing drugs to
treat parasitic and viral diseases, including compounds which are highly active against
human cytomegalovirus, which causes retinitis in AIDS patients, pneumonitis in bone
marrow transplant patients, and is one of the leading causes of birth defects in the U.S.
Professor Townsend is responsible for the discovery of several compounds used to treat
a remarkable variety of serious diseases. He has published over 430 original research
publications and has over 300 abstracts to his credit.


93




September Meeting, 2000


Professor Townsend is a dedicated teacher and mentor of students and research
fellows in pharmacy, medicinal chemistry, and chemistry, having led the medicinal
chemistry graduate program to its place as one of the best in the country. He has served
in many capacities in local, national, and international organizations, including the
position of president and virtually every other elected position of the American
Chemical Society's Division of Medicinal Chemistry. He has received numerous
awards in recognition of his many significant achievements.
The Regents salute this distinguished scholar by naming Leroy B. Townsend the
Albert B. Prescott Professor Emeritus of Medicinal Chemistry and professor emeritus of
chemistry.
Norman D. Weiner, Ph.D., professor of pharmaceutics in the College of
Pharmacy, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 2000, after 28 years of
service.
Professor Weiner received his B.S. degree in pharmacy from Long Island University's
Brooklyn College of Pharmacy in 1959 and his Ph.D. degree in pharmacy from Columbia
University in 1965. Following graduation, he became an assistant professor of pharmacy at
Columbia University, where he was promoted to associate professor of pharmacy in 1967.
He joined the University of Michigan College of Pharmacy as associate professor in 1972
and achieved the rank of professor in 1977. He was elected as a fellow to the American
Association of Pharmaceutical Scientists in 1990.
Professor Weiner's research achievements have received international acclaim. His
early research focused on the membrane structure of living cells. In collaboration with a
colleague at the University's hearing institute, he began seeking an explanation of why
neomycin and other aminoglycosides were causing irreversible hearing loss when
systematically administered. The accepted theory of the day was that these compounds were
causing irreversible nerve damage, thereby leading to hearing loss. They viewed this theory
as being highly suspect, and in a relentless pursuit, they discovered that the aminoglycosides
were actually interacting with the membranes of hair cells in the inner ear and killing these
cells, thereby, resulting in the loss of hearing. In the course of their work, hearing damage
assessment measures were developed that have been instrumental in preventing future
compounds from sharing the same toxicity, thereby, preventing this type of terrible side
effect from occurring again. Professor Weiner's interests then expanded to include methods
of using liposomes for drug delivery purposes, especially through the skin. First, he
disproved the popular theory of the time that liposomes could be used as an effective method
for delivering drugs orally. In complete contrast, he and his colleagues demonstrated that
they are effective at promoting drug absorption across the skin. These were significant
discoveries that led to Professor Weiner's explorations of the properties of other topical
dosage forms, such as emulsions-also work for which he is well known. His insights
concerning emulsions are not only sought after by pharmaceutical companies, but are of
interest to scientists in other industries, such as oil and food processing companies and
cosmetic manufacturers.
Professor Weiner is a dedicated teacher who has successfully mentored many pharmacy
students, graduate students, and research fellow trainees in his area of expertise. He has
presented his research findings across the globe and has received recognition for his important
contributions.
The Regents salute this distinguished scholar by naming Norman D. Weiner professor
emeritus of pharmaceutics.


94




September Meeting, 2000


Memorials. Vice President Tedesco submitted a memorial statement for Michael
S. Aldrich, M.D., professor of neurology.
The Regents of the University of Michigan acknowledge with profound regret the
death of Michael S. Aldrich, M.D., professor of neurology at the Medical School.
Dr. Aldrich completed his medical education at the University of Virginia in 1980
and received his residency training in neurology at the University of Michigan, where he
remained during a most distinguished career. In 1985, he founded the University of
Michigan Sleep Disorders Laboratory. Under his careful management, the laboratory
grew into an internationally preeminent center for clinical work, education, and research
in sleep medicine.
Dr. Aldrich was best known for his contributions to the diagnosis and management
of narcolepsy and other common causes of pathological sleepiness. He spoke to
audiences around the world, increasing awareness about the pervasive but often
unrecognized effects of sleep disorders. In this country, his influence on education, in
part as president of the American Board of Sleep Medicine, helped to establish a new
clinical science as a regular part of training for countless young clinicians. Here at the
University of Michigan, the sleep disorders program that Dr. Aldrich developed became
a model that others still emulate. His recent text, Sleep Medicine, received widespread
acclaim as a precise, clear, yet lively introduction to a field the author helped to develop.
Dr. Aldrich's remarkable professional accomplishments were no less impressive
than the personal characteristics that made him among the most admired and best liked
faculty. For nearly two decades, Dr. Aldrich served as a consummate role model for
students, residents, fellows, and junior faculty at the University of Michigan, universally
respected for his collegial but professional attitude, calm though effective demeanor,
and quiet yet invaluable wisdom. Many patients considered him their best physician,
trainees their most authoritative teacher, and faculty their most reliable colleague.
As sincerely as Dr. Aldrich will be missed by his peers, our condolences are
extended in particular to those who appreciated him most: his wife Leslie; children
Jenny, Matt, and Brian; siblings Carol, Thomas, and Robert; and parents Julie and
Knight.
To the extent that the University of Michigan can claim some credit for his
education, Dr. Aldrich was among its proudest achievements. With intelligence,
ingenuity, and exemplary dedication, Dr. Aldrich returned an initial investment many
times over, reminding us of the unique potential we have as a University to improve the
education, careers, health, and well-being of future generations.
Degrees. There are no actions with respect to degrees this month.
Consent Agenda Approval. On a motion by Regent Horning, seconded by
Regent McGowan, the Regents unanimously approved the consent agenda.

University of Michigan Medical School Wall Street Research Laboratory Building

that building. The Wall Street Research Laboratory Building is proposed for this


96




September Meeting, 2000


purpose.  Executive Vice President Kasdin commented that plans are to move
expeditiously with preparation and approval of design plans so that construction can
proceed as quickly as possible. He noted that he believes the building is responsive to
issues that have been raised by the community for this area. While he recommends
proceeding with the proposed research laboratory building as described, he noted that
the University welcomes continuing discussion with community members over future
plans for the Wall Street area.

unanimously approved proceeding with the Wall Street Research Laboratory Building
project utilizing the Smith Group for programming and design. Design approval will be
sought following completion of the schematic design documents.

information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:

Housing Department and What Is It This Week.
2.   The service provided was silk screening of shirts, in April 2000, at a total cost of
$400.00.
3.   The pecuniary interest arises from the fact that Susan Fisher, a University of Michigan
employee, is sole owner of What Is It This Week.

Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and Keracure
LLC
On a motion by Regent Brandon, seconded by Regent McGowan, the Regents
unanimously approved a license agreement between the University of Michigan and
Keracure LLC. Because the developer of the technology, Riley Rees, is a University of
Michigan employee and holds an equity interest in Keracure LLC, this agreement falls
under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is
provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and Keracure LLC.
2.   Contract terms include:
The contract to be completed between the University of Michigan and Keracure LLC
consists of a license agreement to be executed by authorized representatives of the
parties;


98




September Meeting, 2000


The license grants to Keracure, for TMO File Nos. 1203 and 1654: an exclusive,
worldwide license, including the right to sublicense, to make, have made, import, use,
market, offer for sale and sell, products incorporating the technology;
The University will receive a one time, license issue fee of $50,000;
The University will receive a royalty of 3%, based upon a running royalty on net sales
of licensed products;
The University will receive 50% of any sublicensing fees;
The University will receive annual maintenance fees in 2002 of $10,000, in 2003 of
$25,000, and each year thereafter of $50,000;
The University will receive Milestone payments of $50,000 for FDA approval of File
No. 1203 technology; $100,000 upon initiation of Phase I Clinical Trials for File No.
1654 technology; $200,000 upon initiation of Phase III Clinical Trials for File No.
1654 technology; and $500,000 for FDA approval for File No. 1654 technology;
The University will receive reimbursement for all patent costs;
The University will receive an undiluted 3% of equity in the form of common stock at
the point of time when Keracure LLC has raised $2.5 million in any combination of
debt or sale of equity;
The Term of the agreement is for the life of the patents;
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under the agreement.
3.   Dr. Riley Rees' pecuniary interest arises from his ownership in Keracure. He has
waived any personal participation in the sharing of royalties received by the University
from the company.
Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and Molecular
Therapeutics, Inc.
On a motion by Regent Taylor, seconded by Regent Maynard, all six Regents
present unanimously approved a proposed license agreement between the University of
Michigan and Molecular Therapeutics, Inc. (Regent Brandon was away from the table
for this and the succeeding four votes, and Regent Deitch was absent.)
Because the principal owners of Molecular Therapeutics, Inc., Brian D. Ross and
Alnawaz Rehemtulla, are also University of Michigan employees and developers of the
technology, this agreement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute.
The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and Molecular Therapeutics,
Inc.
2.   Licensing terms include:
Field of use: Molecular reporter technology for the detection of proteolytic activity
related to any disease;
Exclusive worldwide license, with a right to grant sublicenses to Technology as
defined by TMO File No. 1835;
A license fee of $20,000.00 to be applied to reimbursement of patent expenses and/or
applied against royalties. An initial payment of $5,000.00 due upon license execution;
$5,000.00 due upon the first anniversary of signing; and $10,000 due upon the second
anniversary of signing. These monies will constitute reimbursement of current patent
costs;
Maintenance fees of $20,000.00 per year to be credited against all cumulative research
funds for a period of 5 years. Subsequent annual fees can then be offset by royalties;
The University of Michigan will take a 3% equity position on the first 12,000 shares
issued by Molecular Therapeutics, Inc.;
All remaining current and future U.S. and foreign patent costs will be paid by
Molecular Therapeutics, Inc.;


99




September Meeting, 2000


Royalties to the University of 3% on Net Sales of Products and 1% on Net Sales of all
Services using this technology. The first approximately $100,000 in royalties would be
offset by patent costs. Sublicensing royalties will be 3% of Net Sublicense Revenue
provided Molecular Therapeutics can make available a Net Sublicense Revenue
justification;
Specified milestones must be met in order to maintain the rights granted by the license;
The University will retain ownership of the licensed technology and may continue to
further develop it and use it as a research tool;
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under the agreement.
3.   The pecuniary interests of both Brian D. Ross and Alnawaz Rehemtulla arise from their
ownership in the company. Both Drs. Ross and Rehemtulla have waived any personal
participation in the sharing of funds received by the University from Molecular
Therapeutics, Inc. as a result of this License Agreement.
Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and MEMS
Technology, LLC
On a motion by Regent Maynard, seconded by Regent White, the Regents
unanimously approved a license agreement between the University of Michigan and
MEMS Technology ("MEMS Tech") for the commercialization of inventions developed
and owned by the University of Michigan. MEMS Tech and Professor Richard B.
Brown have started a company, SENSation, Inc. ("SENSation") for this purpose.
Because Richard B. Brown is both an owner of the company and a University of
Michigan employee, this agreement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of
Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory
requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and MEMS Tech, a parent
company to SENSation, the company in which Richard B. Brown will hold an equity
interest.
2.   Licensing terms include:
Exclusive rights to practice and commercialize the technology, subject to certain rights
reserved by the University to practice it for research and educational purposes, with
right to grant sublicenses. The University retains ownership;
The University will receive 2-5% equity of SENSation;
A License issue fee of $5,000-30,000 to be applied to reimbursement of patent
expenses and/or applied against royalties;
Royalties to the University of 15-17% of total non-product revenues received by
SENSation, and 1-2% of net sales of products by SENSation;
Specified milestones will be met in order to maintain the rights granted by the license.
Payments will be made as maintenance fees or related to specific performance criteria.
Each payment will not exceed $20,000;
All remaining current and future U.S. and foreign patent costs will be paid by licensee;
Term of the agreement is for the life of the patents;
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under this agreement.
3.   Richard B. Brown's pecuniary interest arises from  his ownership interest in
SENSation. He has waived any personal participation in the sharing of royalties
received by the University from the licensee.

Non-exclusive right to practice and commercialize the technology, subject to certain
rights reserved by the University in order to meet a potential obligation to exclusively
license the technology under an option agreement in a limited field of use to a specific
research sponsor. The University retains ownership;
Primarily limited to internal use, with a limited right to provide software to others for
demonstration purposes;
Term of the agreement is for the life of the patents;
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under the agreement;

Signal. He has waived any personal participation in the sharing of royalties received

Materials, Inc. Because Richard M. Laine is both a University employee who will be
participating in the project on behalf of the University, and is also an officer and majority
shareholder of Tal Materials, Inc., this agreement falls under the State of Michigan
Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with
statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and Tal Materials, Inc.
2.   The terms of the proposed Agreement are acceptable and conform to University policy.
This project will provide support for Dr. Ryo Tamaki, a postdoctoral fellow, over the
term of the Agreement. The total award under this Agreement will not exceed $40,000
over a two year period. The initial award is in the amount of $14,188 and will provide
fifty percent (50%) support of Dr. Tamaki over a three month period. The College of
Engineering supports this agreement.

shareholder of Tal Materials, Inc.

Lisa A. Tedesco
Vice President and Secretary of the University


102




OCTOBER MEETING, 2000


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, October 19, 2000
The Regents convened at 3:00 p.m. in the Michigan Rooms of the Harding Mott
University Center on the campus of the University of Michigan-Flint. Present were
President Bollinger and Regents Brandon, Deitch, Horning, Maynard, McGowan,
Newman, Taylor, and White. Also present were Provost Cantor, Vice President Feagin,
Interim Vice President Harper, Executive Vice President Kasdin, Vice President and
General Counsel Krislov, Chancellor Little, Chancellor Mestas, Vice President Rudgers,
Vice President and Secretary Tedesco, Vice President Ulaby, and Vice President
Wilbanks. Executive Vice President Omenn was absent.
"Michigan Greats"
President Bollinger called the meeting to order and called on Vice President Ulaby.
Vice President Ulaby introduced Professor Lois Alexander, chair of the Department of
Music at the University of Michigan-Flint. Professor Alexander noted that "Michigan
Greats" would feature the University of Michigan-Flint's Gospel Choir, directed by
Professor Carl Byerly.  Professor Byerly then led the choir in a twenty-minute
performance, which was followed by a round of applause.
President Bollinger thanked Chancellor Mestas for hosting the Regents' Meeting
and commented on the beauty and pleasant atmosphere of the Flint campus.
State Budget Requests - All Three Campuses
Ann Arbor Campus. Provost Cantor reported that the Ann Arbor campus had
recently been reaccredited by the North Central Association. She expressed thanks to state
legislators for the 5.7% funding increase for the current fiscal year, which, combined with
the 4.8% increase for the previous year, had allowed the University to keep its annual
tuition increase below 3% for two years in a row, compared to a national average increase
of 5% overall and 4.4% for public, 4-year universities.
Regarding the reaccreditation effort, Provost Cntor reported that the University had
pursued a "special emphasis" on the topic of interdisciplinary and collaborative work at
the University. Four working groups, coordinated by Mr. John Godfrey, had been
formed to examine how collaborative and interdisciplinary work allows people to take
full advantage of the campus's intellectual and social richness. The reaccreditation had
been granted with no contingency.
Provost Cantor observed that the reaccreditation team had praised the University's
atmosphere of intellectual freedom, and she said that "the dynamic coexistence of two
successful traditions, decentralization and connectivity, helps to distinguish the
University of Michigan as an international leader in higher education." She observed
that the state budget request reflects the theme of connectivity and attempts to build on
the University's social and intellectual nimbleness. It examines the mutual benefits
bestowed on both undergraduates and faculty from interaction and immersion in each
other's world.


103




October Meeting, 2000


The University is seeking an increase of 6% in state appropriation with two special
emphases that reflect the theme of the reaccreditation exercise: enhancing the contexts
within which faculty and students interact through such themes as economic and
environmental sustainability and expanding undergraduate residential living experiences
in keeping with the theme of providing learning environments that stretch beyond the
traditional classroom.
President Bollinger observed that the accreditation experience had been very
meaningful and that the University had been gratified by the reactions of the
distinguished members of the visiting accrediting team. He pointed out that in response
to concerns about the cost of higher education, the average tuition increase during the
four years of his administration has been limited to 3.3%, which is the lowest in
decades. Tuition for a resident undergraduate student, which is an "unbelievable
bargain," is only 25% of the cost of a comparable education at a private university.
Dearborn Campus. Chancellor Little observed that the Dearborn campus is
preparing for an anticipated growth rate of 3% per year for the next few years. The
central focus of the budget request involves strengthening and broadening the faculty
and reducing the percentage of adjunct faculty. Program growth will be examined and
targeted in specific areas to enhance the campus's ability to meet the educational needs
of southeast Michigan.  Information technology needs will be addressed and
interdisciplinary and community-outreach initiatives will be expanded as well. The
total request is for a base increase of $2,785,000 and a one-time additional allocation of
$750,000 for information technology.
Flint Campus. Chancellor Mestas indicated that the Flint campus request focuses
on four areas: continuing to provide top-quality undergraduate and graduate education
at an affordable price; incrementally strengthening new academic program initiatives;
expanding informational and instructional technology, especially in academic areas; and
enhancing community outreach efforts to the City of Flint and the surrounding area. He
noted that the University of Michigan-Flint is one of the most valuable resources in an
area that has many challenges and that the University needs to continue contributing to
the development of the Flint area.
Chancellor Mestas reported that an enrollment management study has been
completed, and the survey's recommendations will serve as the basis for discussion,
involving all elements of the campus community, about the future of the University.
Regent Taylor moved approval of the state budget request for the Ann Arbor
Campus. Regent White seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Regent Newman moved approval of the state budget request for the Dearborn
Campus. Regent White seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Regent Newman moved approval of the state budget request for the Flint Campus.
Regent Taylor seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Consent Agenda
Minutes.  Vice President Tedesco submitted the Minutes of the meeting of
September 21-22, 2000.

Personnel Actions. Provost Cantor submitted a number of Personnel Actions and
Personnel Reports. She commented on the appointment of Susan Walz as professor of
public policy in the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy. Executive Vice President
Kasdin highlighted the appointment of Barbara Butterfield as associate vice president
for human resources and affirmative action and chief human resources officer. Vice
President Wilbanks called attention to the appointment of Michael Waring as executive
director of federal relations and executive director of the Washington, D.C. office.

Retirement Memoirs.        Vice President Tedesco submitted for adoption four
retirement memoirs.


125




October Meeting, 2000


Paul S. Fancher, Jr., senior research scientist in the University of Michigan
Transportation Research Institute, retired from active faculty status on September 15,
2000.
Paul Fancher received his B.S. degree in engineering mechanics, his M.S.E. degree
in instrumentation, and his professional degree (INS.E.) in instrumentation engineering
from the University of Michigan in 1953, 1959, and 1964 respectively. He joined the
University in 1957 as a research assistant at the Institute of Science and Technology
(IST) and progressed to an associate research engineer. In 1969, he joined the Highway
Safety Research Institute, where he was promoted to research scientist in 1970 and senior
research scientist in 1997. From 1986-89, Mr. Fancher served as the acting head of the
Engineering Research Division of the University of Michigan Transportation Research
Institute and, until his retirement, as the division's associate head.  He has served as
co-chair of the Summer Conference on the Mechanics of Heavy Duty Truck Systems
since 1992.
Mr. Fancher sought to improve analytical understanding of complex mechanical
systems, particularly as they relate to automobile and heavy truck safety improvements.
His modeling and analysis concepts have aided the effort by automobile and heavy truck
makers around the world to develop "active safety" technologies meant to assist the
driver in safe and convenient control of the motor vehicle. During the 1990s, his
research focused on adaptive cruise control and collision warning applications; he is a
leading analyst of these "intelligent" forms of active-safety technology. His research has
combined philosophical principles with scientific knowledge of human performance,
engineering mechanics, and control systems theory to effect remarkably simple schema
for representing the technologically-assisted driving process. His achievements were
honored in 1997 with the National Award for the Advancement of Motor Vehicle
Research and Development, established by Congress as the highest national recognition
given in this field. He is a fellow of the Society of Automotive Engineers and served for
many years as the chair of its Vehicle Dynamics Forum Committee. He also held
leadership positions in the International Association for Vehicle System Dynamics, the
Transportation Research Board, and the International Standards Organization.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Paul S. Fancher, Jr., senior
research scientist emeritus.
Walter J. Loesche, D.M.D., Ph.D., the Marcus L. Ward Professor of Dentistry,
professor of dentistry, Department of Biologic and Materials Sciences in the School of
Dentistry, and professor of microbiology in the Medical School, retired from active
faculty status on August 31, 2000.
Dr. Loesche received his B.A. degree from Yale University in 1957, his D.M.D.
degree from Harvard School of Dental Medicine in 1961, his periodontal certificate from
Harvard-Forsyth in 1964, and his Ph.D. degree from Massachusetts Institute of
Technology in 1967. While earning his degrees, he held various positions at Forsyth
Dental Center, Harvard School of Medicine, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
He joined the faculty in 1969 as an associate professor of dentistry and in 1971 he was
appointed associate professor of microbiology in the Medical School. He was promoted
to professor of dentistry and professor of microbiology in 1974 and served as director of
research in the School of Dentistry from 1987-89. He was appointed the Marcus L. Ward
Professor of Dentistry in 1996.


126




October Meeting, 2000


Dr. Loesche's work was key in changing our understanding of both cavities and
periodontal disease by recognizing them as bacterial infections. His research involving
bacterial anaerobes and their role in periodontal disease lead to the use of metronidazole
or doxycycline as treatment alternatives to surgical intervention for these conditions. In
recognition of his work, in 1988 a new species of gram-negative anaerobic rods isolated
from the oral cavity was named Bacteroides loescheii.
An extremely creative and productive researcher, Dr. Loesche has had continuous
funding since 1970 and has published 3 textbooks, over 170 peer-reviewed articles, and
over 50 chapters and invited reviews.  He has served on the editorial boards of
professional journals and on numerous school, university, and national committees. He
currently serves as president of the International Society for Breath Odor Research.
The Regents salute this distinguished health sciences educator by naming Walter J.
Loesche the Marcus L. Ward Professor Emeritus of Dentistry, professor emeritus of
dentistry, and professor emeritus of microbiology.
Harrison L. Morton, Ph.D., professor of forest pathology, School of Natural
Resources and Environment, will retire from active faculty status on October 31, 2000.
A native of Minnesota, Professor Morton received his B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees
from the University of Minnesota in 1961, 1964, and 1967, respectively. He joined the
University of Michigan as an assistant professor of forest pathology in 1966 and was
promoted to associate professor in 1969 and professor of forest pathology in 1978.
Professor Morton served as chair of the forestry department and chair of the fisheries,
forestry, and wildlife program. He also served as director, University of Michigan
Nichols Arboretum, from  1986-99, acting dean from  1988-89, associate dean for
administration from 1990-92, interim dean 1991-92, and associate dean, School of
Natural Resources and Environment from 1992-99.
Professor Morton's teaching and research focused on the area of tree diseases. He
taught introductory and advanced forest pathology courses to students interested in forest
production and tree health. He also introduced an undergraduate course in urban forestry,
encouraging many stuenouraging many students to pursue professional careers with municipalities and the
green industry. With a basic interest in microbiology, Professor Morton's research
involved tdecay. Particularly interested in                 Michigan Christmas
trees, he described new major foliage diseases on Douglas-fir and unraveled the biology
and then disease control using chemical, cultural, and genetic resistance techniques.
Professor Morton served as director of Nichols Arboretum from 1986-99. In this
role, he initiated major programs in support of student research and established a Friends
group, a newsletter, and a volunteer docent organization. Through his leadership, funds
were raised to move the historic Burnham House to the Arb where it now functions as the
Reader Educational Center and home for Arboretum staff. Within the community,
Professor Morton instituted Ann Arbor's "tree clinics" and lent his professional expertise
to homeowners, UM staff, the Michigan Forestry and Park Association, and the legal
profession in the areas of liability and valuation.
The Regents salute this distinguished scholar by naming Harrison L. Morton
professor emeritus of forest pathology.
H. Dennis Smith, professor of music (trombone), retired from active faculty
status on May 31, 2000.
Professor Smith received his B.M. degree in music education from the University of
Southern California in 1960. He held teaching positions at Brigham Young University


127




October Meeting, 2000


and the University of Utah (1964-68), the Music Academy of the West-Santa Barbara
(1965-68), California Institute for the Arts (1971-74), California State College-Fullerton
(1973-74), Western Washington University (1974-79), and California State
University-Northridge (1979-80). He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1980
as an associate professor and was promoted to professor in 1986.
Before joining the faculty at the University of Michigan, Professor Smith held posts
as principal trombonist with the Utah Symphony Orchestra (1964-68), Detroit Symphony
Orchestra (1968-71), and the Los Angeles Philharmonic (1971-74). He is a former
member of the Los Angeles Brass Quintet, the University of Utah Brass Quintet,
Symphonic Metamorphosis (London Records), the Brass Arts Trio (University of Puget
Sound), and the Second City Chamber Series of Tacoma, Washington, and he was
founder and former member of the Brass Arts Quintet of New York. He was the principal
trombonist with the Toledo Symphony from 1982 until his retirement, performing over
40 concerts yearly.
Professor Smith was an exceptional and valuable teacher and mentor, able to attract
high quality students who were well trained musically and technically. Throughout his
years at Michigan, Professor Smith shared his talent by performing at numerous high
schools and community colleges in Michigan and Ohio. He was recognized as an
excellent musician and recording artist, whose most recent recording is "The All
American Trombone." Professor Smith was an exceptional colleague, a leader nationally
in the development of trombone repertoire, and a contributing member of the School of
Music community.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming H. Dennis Smith professor
emeritus of music (trombone).
Memorials. Vice President Tedesco submitted three memorial statements for
three active faculty members.
The Regents of the University of Michigan acknowledge with profound sadness the
death of Gary R. Bird, assistant professor of music (musical theatre), School of Music.
Professor Bird received his B.S. degree in theatre from Weber State University in
1976 and his M.F.A. degree in theatre from the University of Utah in 1979. He began his
professional career as assistant professor of theatre at Brigham Young University at
Hawaii in 1979, transferring to Utah State University in 1980. In 1991, Professor Bird
accepted a position at East Carolina University, where he taught until he joined the
faculty at the University of Michigan in 1994. He came to the School of Music with over
ten years of teaching experience in the musical theatre field and had directed more than
50 plays and musicals in academic, community, and professional settings.
His first production at the University of Michigan was Grand Hotel in April
1996, followed by The Mystery of Edwin Drood (October 1996), West Side Story (April
1998), Anything Goes (October 1998), and A Little Night Music (1999). The Ann Arbor
News heralded his direction of West Side Story as "an astonishing new spin on a
Broadway classic." In the spring of 2000, Professor Bird directed theatre department
students in a studio production of the musical Personals. He and the musical theatre
students were looking forward to producing a studio production of Sondheim's Assassins
in December 2000, which the department will continue in Professor Bird's honor. He
taught courses in musical theatre performance, a subject about which he was writing a
book.


128




October Meeting, 2000


As a teacher, Professor Bird influenced his students at all times.  A
much-repeated remembrance of him summarizes the feelings of many: "Professor Bird
helped me to grow as a person and as a performer. He helped me to reach heights I never
knew I could." A favorite with the students, however, was Professor Bird's unique sense
of humor and engaging smile.
Revered and respected by his friends and colleagues in the School of Music,
Professor Bird will be sorely missed by those who had the privilege of knowing him. His
sudden and premature death is an incalculable loss for the University community. As we
mourn the loss of this distinguished scholar and gifted artist, we unite in extending our
condolences to Professor Bird's children, Tyler, Chelsea, and Bethany; his parents, Mr.
and Mrs. Robert Bird; and the rest of his family.
Cloyzelle K. Jones, Ed.D., professor of education, died on August 21, 2000.
Professor Jones received his Ed.D. degree from Wayne State University. He joined
the faculty of the University of Michigan-Dearborn in 1970. He was instrumental in the
growth of the education unit from a program in liberal arts, to a division of urban
education, and finally, to a school of education.
Professor Jones had a lifelong interest in urban education and was founder of the
National Urban Education Association. He was a frequent guest on local radio stations
as a commentator on urban education problems. He was an advisor to the Michigan
Detroit Association of Black Organizations, and New Detroit.
Professor Jones was a mentor for a generation of African-American students. He
was a frequent speaker in Detroit schools, a successful fundraiser for minority student
support, an advocate of alternative schools, and a member of several doctoral committees
at Wayne State University and the University of Michigan. He was a member of the
Council for Exceptional Children and Neighborhood Legal Services.
Hundreds of students benefited from Professor Jones' courses in multicultural
education. Unfortunately, Professor Jones' career was hampered by long term illness.
As we mourn the loss of this courageous faculty member, our condolences go to his
family members, Mr. and Mrs. Cloyzelle K. Jones, Mr. and Mrs. Derek Moss, Mr.
Kreigh V. Jones, Ms. Keitia Jones, Ms. Keli Jones, and Mr. Vernon W. Jones.
The Regents of the University of Michigan acknowledge with profound sadness the
death on Monday, October 2, 2000, of Emmanuel-George Vakalo, associate professor
of architecture, A. Alfred Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning.
Born in Athens, Greece, Professor Vakalo served in the Royal Greek Air Force
before coming to America to study. He first studied at Cornell University in Ithaca, New
York, receiving his bachelor's and master's degrees in architecture and his master's
degree in regional planning. He then moved to Ann Arbor to pursue a doctoral degree in
Urban, Technological, and Environmental Planning, which he received in 1985.
Professor Vakalo joined the architecture program faculty in 1979, where his
command of the art of teaching was recognized immediately. With gentle firmness and a
determination to be understood, Professor Vakalo remained enthusiastic and passionate
about teaching throughout his career. He took the time to know his students as
individuals and demanded rigor and commitment from each. The students responded
with enthusiasm to this demanding but humane pedagogue. One way in which Vakalo's
teaching quality was recognized was through his receipt of the Sol King Award for
Excellence in Teaching.


129




October Meeting, 2000


Professor Vakalo was a valued and trusted colleague as well as a beloved mentor to
the junior faculty. He used his superb teaching and coaching skills to help them adjust to
the academy and for many he remained a continuing source of guidance and support
throughout their careers.
From 1994-99, Professor Vakalo chaired the Doctoral Program in Architecture. An
expert on computer modeling and shape grammar, he shared his own particular research
agenda with students. In addition, he exposed them to the many modalities available to
formulate a vigorous research agenda that would further their success within the program
and in their careers after graduation.
As we mourn the loss of this distinguished teacher, mentor, friend, scholar, and
artist, our condolences go to his wife Kathleen, and his mother Eleni Vakalo, who lives
in Greece.
Degrees. Provost Cantor submitted for approval final degree lists for the May
2000 Law School commencement and for the August 2000 commencements for other
schools, colleges, divisions, and branch campuses. She also submitted a number of
changes to previously approved degree lists. Copies of all of the degree lists are on file
in the Office of the Vice President and Secretary of the University.
On a motion by Regent Maynard, seconded by Regent McGowan, the Regents
unanimously approved the Consent Agenda.

131




October Meeting, 2000


Mary Berry-Bovia is both a university of Michigan employee and a partial owner and
stockholder of Life Support Services, Inc., this contract falls under the State of Michigan
Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with
statutory requirements:
1.   The parties to the purchase contracts will be the Regents of the University of Michigan
and Life Support Services, Inc.
2.   The terms of the contracts are to provide training for a period beginning July 1, 2000
through June 30, 2002, for amounts not to exceed $54,000 for Cardiac Arrest
Competency Training, $90,000 for Basic Cardiac Life Support Training, and $8,000
for Neonatal Resuscitation Training.

Michigan employee and a partial owner and stockholder of Life Support Services, Inc.

On a motion by Regent Brandon, seconded by Regent Maynard, the Regents
unanimously approved processing payment for artwork by James Cogswell, Jr. Because
James Cogswell, Jr. is a University employee and would also be a party to the contract by
virtue of his being the artist who created and owns the artwork to be purchased, this
purchase falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following
information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   The parties to the contract are the Regents of the University of Michigan and its
Hatcher Graduate Library and Associate Professor James Cogswell, Jr.
2.   The artwork to be purchased is five unframed woodblock prints at a total cost of
$3,000.00.
3.   The pecuniary interest arises from the fact that James Cogswell, Jr., a University of
Michigan employee, is the owner/creator of the artwork to be purchased.
License Agreement between the University of Michigan and Arbor Networks
On a motion by Regent White, seconded by Regent Horning, the Regents
unanimously approved a license agreement with Arbor Networks for three inventions,
identified as file numbers 1900, 1920, and 1921 in the Technology Management Office.
Because the inventors of the technologies, Farnam Jahanian and Gerald R. (Rob) Malan,
are University of Michigan employees and also hold equity interest in Arbor Networks,
Inc., this agreement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The
following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   The parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and Arbor Networks, Inc.
2.   Contract terms include:
Exclusive right to practice and commercialize the technology, subject to certain rights
reserved by the University to practice it for research and educational purposes, with
right to grant sub-licenses.
The University will receive a 5% equity share in Arbor Networks. This position will
be protected against dilution up through $5 million of investment in Arbor Networks.
Arbor Networks will support College of Engineering research at a level of at least
$50,000/year for a minimum of three years.
Specified milestones will be met in order to maintain the rights granted by the license.
All remaining current and future U.S. and foreign patent costs will be paid by the
licensee.
Term of the agreement is for the life of the patents.
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under this agreement.


132




October Meeting, 2000


3.   Farnam Jahnanian's pecuniary interest arises from his ownership interest in Arbor
Networks. He has waived any personal participation in the sharing of royalties
received by the University from the company.
Gerald Malan's pecuniary interest arises from his personal founders share in Arbor
Networks. He has waived any personal participation in the sharing of royalties
received by the University from the company.
Research Agreement between the University of Michigan and the Great Lakes
Commission

unanimously approved a research agreement between the University of Michigan and the
Great Lakes Commission. Because the project involves collaboration with Dr. Michael
Donahue, who is employed by the Great Lakes Commission and is also an adjunct faculty
member at the University of Michigan, this agreement falls under the State of Michigan
Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with
statutory requirements:
1.   The parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and the Great Lakes
Commission.
2.   Under the project a total subcontract of approximately $28,586 is anticipated to cover
the period of July 1, 2000 through September 30, 2002. The terms of the proposed
agreement are acceptable and conform to University policy.
3.   Michael Donahue's adjunct appointment at the University of Michigan is without
compensation.
Research Agreement between the University of Michigan and HealthMedia, Inc.

unanimously approved a research agreement between the University of Michigan and
HealthMedia, Inc. Because Victor Strecher is both a University of Michigan employee
and partial owner and chief scientific officer of HealthMedia, Inc., this agreement falls
under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is
provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and HealthMedia, Inc.
2.   The terms of the agreement are acceptable and conform to University policy. The
amount of the subcontract to the University if $279,591. The period of performance is
one year.
3.   Victor Stretcher's pecuniary interest arises from his part-ownership of HealthMedia,
Inc. and his role as chief scientific officer. He will devote no effort to this project on
behalf of the University and has played no role in the proposal submission or
negotiation of an agreement with the University.

Resolution in Honor of Olympic Athletes
The following Olympics participants with University of Michigan affiliations were
introduced and called to the podium: swimmers Tom Dolan, Tom Malchow, Chris
Thompson, Marcel Wouda, Samantha Arsenault; Bernice Orwig (women's water polo);
and Jennifer Brundage (softball) (all medal winners). Also introduced were Mike McWha
and Owen VonRichter (swimming team members), Jon Urbanchek (men's swimming
coach), Kevin Sullivan (cross country team member), Ron Warhurst (cross country
coach), and Rich Fetchiet (baseball umpire).
Speaking on behalf of all of the Olympic participants, Tom Dolan observed that it
was an honor for athletes to represent their countries in the Olympics but "it's nicer to
be able to come back as part of the University of Michigan family." He noted that while
athletes strive to be successful in their own sport, to have the link of all having been
teammates regardless of what country one is from or represents at the games, the fact
that they have all been teammates is what really means a lot to them as athletes. He said
that "it is an honor to be part of the University of Michigan and the academics and
athletics that it has offered us and given us a chance to be a part of, and we feel very
special to have done that." He thanked the Regents for inviting the athletes to receive a
resolution and for feeling "part of the great family that is the University of Michigan."
A round of applause followed.
Regent White read the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan applaud the
University's Olympic athletes for their commitment to athletic excellence
and for their superb performances at the Twenty-seventh Olympiad. The
2000 Olympic games long will be remembered for the nine medals won
by the University of Michigan's athletes, as well as for the intensity,
resolve, and sportsmanship exhibited by all of Michigan's student
athletes, alumni, and coaches who participated in this summer's games.
It is with great pride that the Regents commend swimmers Tom
Dolan (gold and silver), Tom Malchow (gold), Samantha Arsenault


134




October Meeting, 2000


(gold), Chris Thompson (bronze), Marcel Wouda (bronze), and Gustavo
Borges (bronze); assistant women's softball coach Jennifer Brundage
(gold), a member of the United States softball team; assistant women's

water polo team; and men's swimming coach Jon Urbanchek for his
leadership as assistant coach of the U.S. Men's Olympic Swimming
Team.

Resolution in Honor of Mayor Ingrid Sheldon
Regent Brandon called Mayor Ingrid Sheldon to the podium. He observed that he
took particular pride in presenting this resolution, as he had known Mayor Sheldon for
many years, beginning when she was his third grade Sunday school teacher. He then read
the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan congratulate and
extend their warmest best wishes to Ingrid B. Sheldon as she concludes
her fourth term as mayor of Ann Arbor.
Her deep love of the city, its residents, and its institutions,
including the University of Michigan, is evident in Mayor Sheldon's
ubiquitous presence in the community and a leadership style marked by
openness to new ideas, decisiveness, and trust. A lifelong Ann Arbor
resident and enthusiastic Michigan alumna, Mayor Sheldon was elected
mayor in 1993 after serving two terms on City Council. In a city with an
extraordinarily demanding constituency, she has governed wisely, with
wit, charm, and a respectfor colleagues and constituents.


135




October Meeting, 2000


Mayor Sheldon has served on numerous boards and committees,
including the City/Universit Committee, Downtown Marketing Task
Force, Ann Arbor Historical Foundation, and the Ann Arbor/Ypsilanti
Urban Area Transportation Study Committee.  She serves on the
Southeast Michigan Council of Governments (SEMCOG) Executive
Board and is vice-chair of SEMCOG's Community and Economic
Development Advisoty Council. She also is influencing public policy
more broadly as president of the Michigan Municipal League and
through her activities with the U.S. Conference of Mayors. Mayor
Sheldon has received numerous accolades, including the Huron Valley
Girl Scout Council Woman of Distinction Award, Rotary Club of Ann
Arbor Distinguished Service Award, and the United Way Heart of Gold
Award.
With deep appreciation, the Regents congratulate and cotmmend
Ingrid Sheldon for outstanding civic leadership, and for fostering a
cooperative spirit between the City of Ann Arbor and the University of
Michigan that has encouraged both to flourish.
A round of applause followed, after which Mayor Sheldon thanked the Regents
and commented on the long association she and her family have had with the University
of Michigan. She noted that the city works hard to ensure that the University is "the
number one institution and number one community to host that institution."
Life Sciences Institute Co-Directors
President Bollinger called to the podium Professor Jack Dixon, newly appointed
co-director of the Life Sciences Institute and noted that with the appointments of him and
Scott Emr, the University has obtained the best possible leadership for this institute.

institute underway and thanked President Bollinger and the Regents for their leadership
and foresight which led to the University's current leadership position nationally in the
