Sochalski, Julie A., Associate Professor of Nursing, School of Nursing, originally approved November
2000


310




June Meeting, 2001


Retirement Memoirs.    Vice President Tedesco submitted for adoption 33
retirement memoirs.
A. Adnan Aswad, Ph.D., professor of industrial and manufacturing systems
engineering in the College of Engineering and Computer Science, University of
Michigan-Dearborn, retired from active faculty status on April 30, 2001, after many
years of faithful and dedicated service.
Professor Aswad received his B.S. degree in mechanical engineering in 1955 from
Robert College in Turkey. He received his M.S. degrees in mechanical engineering
(1961) and industrial engineering (1964) and his Ph.D. degree in industrial engineering
in 1972 from the University of Michigan. He joined the University of
Michigan-Dearborn faculty as a lecturer in 1965 and was promoted to associate
professor in 1972 and professor in 1983. He served as chair of the Department of
Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering from 1972-83 and was associate
dean of the School of Engineering (now known as the College of Engineering and
Computer Science), from 1983-88.
Professor Aswad has over forty years of professional experience in education,
industry, and as a consultant in the United States and abroad. He was an early and
leading proponent for strengthening manufacturing engineering education. Professor
Aswad is nationally and internationally recognized as a leading authority on quality
function deployment and quality systems. He has published widely and has conducted
research as a visiting scholar in England and Japan.
Professor Aswad was elected as a fellow of the Institute of Industrial Engineers in
1991. Other honors include the Distinguished Faculty Award (1988), Distinguished
Teaching Award (1992), and the Outstanding Service Award (1993). He received a
Distinguished Faculty Award from the Michigan Association of Governing Boards of
State Universities in 1996 and received the Alumni Society's Faculty of the Year Award
in 2000.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming A. Adnan
Aswad professor emeritus of industrial and manufacturing systems engineering.
Oscar A. Barbarin III, Ph.D., professor of social work, School of Social Work,
and professor of psychology, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, retired from
active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Barbarin received his A.B. degree from St. Joseph's Seminary College in
1968, his M.A. degree from New York University in 1971, and his M.S. and Ph.D.
degrees from Rutgers University in 1973 and 1975, respectively. He joined the
University of Michigan faculty in 1979 as assistant professor of psychology. He was
named assistant professor of social work in 1984, associate professor in 1985, and
professor in 1991. He was appointed adjunct associate professor of psychology in 1986
and professor of psychology in 1992.
Professor Barbarin's research focused on the development of culturally-sensitive
assessments of psychological disorders in African-American and Latino children. He
worked with the Detroit Department of Human Services' Head Start program to design
and implement a program of universal preventive screening of psychological and social
risks. In South Africa and Uganda, he pursued projects related to culture and children's
mental health, and many of his papers examine the interplay of the social, emotional,
and academic development of African-American children. From 1996 until January
2000, he was the University's executive director of South African Initiatives, working


311




June Meeting, 2001


with students from professional schools interested in research service projects in
southern Africa.
A productive researcher and scholar, Professor Barbarin collaborated on several
books, including Childhood Cancer and the Family: Meeting the Challenge of Stress
and Social Support; Children with Cancer: School Experiences and Views of Parents,
Educators, Adolescents, and Physicians; and Institutional Racism and Community
Competence. He has also published numerous articles in leading professional journals.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Oscar A.
Barbarin III professor emeritus of social work and professor emeritus of psychology.
Joy Alexander Blouin, senior associate librarian, retired from active faculty status
on January 11, 2001, after twenty-six years of dedicated service.
Ms. Blouin received her B.S. (1967) and M.A. (1969) degrees from Michigan State
University and her A.M.L.S. degree (1977) from the University of Michigan. She
joined the staff of the University Library as a library assistant in 1975. In 1978, she was
appointed assistant curator in the Slide and Photograph Collection in the Department of
History of Art. She was promoted to chief curator of visual resources in 1981. In 1997,
she joined the Media Union Library where she worked to organize and define the visual
collections in support of the School of Art and Design and the A. Alfred Taubman
College of Architecture and Urban Planning.
From 1983-96, Ms. Blouin was editor of the Quarterly Bulletin of the Visual
Resources Association (VRA) and was a member of the association's executive
committee. Under her direction, what had been a newsletter was transformed into the
principal forum on issues regarding art history collections in the United States. For her
achievements, the Visual Resources Association presented Ms. Blouin with its
distinguished service award in 1992 and a special Certificate of Appreciation in 1996.
In the Visual Resources Collections, Ms. Blouin and colleagues authored Michigan
Image Cataloging Software (MICS), a pioneering effort to apply standardized
description to access systems for visual resource collections, which has since been
adopted by a number of other universities. With Professor Graham Smith, she helped
launch the annual History of Art Spring Alumni Seminar in Villa Corsi-Salviati in
Florence, Italy, and organized that seminar for its first ten years. Within the Department
of History of Art, Ms. Blouin was instrumental in creating the Michigan Slide
Distribution project, through which the University of Michigan gained access to
principal  art  collections'  photographic  works,  including  those  of  the
Physsen-Bornemezia (Madrid).
The Regents now salute this distinguished librarian by naming Joy Alexander
Blouin senior associate librarian emerita.
Susan S. Brown, Ph.D., professor of cell and developmental biology, will retire
from active faculty status on July 6, 2001, after a most productive career as a teacher
and researcher.
A native of Virginia, Professor Brown received her B.A. degree at Randolph
Macon Women's College in 1968 and her Ph.D. degree at Harvard University in 1974.
She then carried out postdoctoral studies at the University of California at San Francisco
and Stanford University before joining the University of Michigan faculty as an assistant
professor in 1980. She was promoted to associate professor in 1987 and professor in
1996. She carried out sabbatical studies at Stanford University in 1987 and in Saclay,
France, in 1996.


312




June Meeting, 2001


A meticulous, innovative scientist, in 1992 Professor Brown made a landmark
discovery that changed the way scientists think about the cellular cytoskeleton. This
completely unexpected result has been important in leading researchers to consider new
paradigms for the interaction of cytoskeletal elements. Her extensive publication record
in the very best, broad-based journals, attests not only to the superb quality of Professor
Brown's research, but more importantly to the fact that she asks fundamental questions
with far-reaching impact in many specialized areas.
Professor Brown excels in medical and graduate teaching. Her principal teaching
responsibility has been in medical histology, a 120 hour course offered annually. She
served as course director of medical histology from 1987-94, during the period when the
Medical School curriculum was substantially revised. The transition from the old to the
new curriculum was made virtually seamless for both staff and students due to her
efforts during that period. She also played a major role in teaching cell biology, a core
course for graduate students in the basic medical sciences, and twice served as course
director.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for her dedicated service
by naming Susan S. Brown professor emerita of cell and developmental biology.
Brice Carnahan, Ph.D., professor of chemical and metallurgical engineering,
retired from active faculty status on May 31, 2001, following a 41-year career in the
College of Engineering.
Professor Carnahan received his B.S. (1955) and M.S. (1956) degrees from Case
Institute of Technology and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1965.
He joined the University of Michigan faculty as a lecturer in 1960 and was promoted to
instructor in 1963, assistant professor in 1965, associate professor in 1968, and
professor in 1970.
From 1959-65, Professor Carnahan was technical director of the Ford Foundation
project, "Computers in Engineering Education," and associate director of the NSF
project, "Computers in Engineering Design Education." Since 1960, he has been at the
forefront of computer applications and computing for which he has received national
recognition. In 1969, Professor Carnahan co-authored the landmark text Applied
Numerical Methods. He taught courses on numerical and optimization methods,
computer-aided process design, and material and energy balances. For 25 years, he
presented a popular series of evening lectures on computer programming, typically
attended by 300 enthusiastic participants.  For much of his career, he shared
responsibility for digital computing courses for all engineering freshmen, impacting
some 30,000 students. Twenty-seven different editions of his two course texts have
been published.
Nationally, Professor Carnahan was a founding member of the Computer Aids for
Chemical Engineering Education Committee. He is a fellow of the American Institute
of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) and has served as editor of six of its symposium series
volumes since 1993. Among his honors are the AIChE Computing in Chemical
Engineering Award (1980), the Detroit Engineering Society Chemical Engineer of the
Year Award (1987), and the ASEE Chemical Engineering (3M) Lectureship (1991). He
has received the University's Distinguished Service Award (1968), and the College of
Engineering's Class of 1938 E Service Award (1963), Excellence in Teaching Award
(1983), and Excellence in Service Award (1993).


313




June Meeting, 2001


The Regents salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Brice Carnahan
professor emeritus of chemical and metallurgical engineering.
Bruce Chin, Ph.D., associate professor of environmental health sciences and
associate research scientist in the Institute of Environmental and Industrial Health,
School of Public Health, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Chin received his B.A. degree from Columbia University in 1955 and his
M.S. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Wisconsin in 1957 and 1961,
respectively. He came to the University of Michigan in 1962 as a postdoctoral trainee.
In 1965, he was named instructor in microbiology in the Department of Dermatology
and in 1971 he became a research associate in the Department of Environmental and
Industrial Health (now known as the Department of Environmental Health Sciences) in
the School of Public Health. He was appointed associate professor in 1974. Pursuing
his interest in university administration, in 1982-83 Professor Chin was an American
Council on Education Fellow in Academic Administration. He then served as assistant
dean for academic affairs in the School of Public Health from 1984-87.
Professor Chin's research interests are in the broad area of environmental
toxicology. In particular, he is a highly respected scholar in the areas of risk assessment,
communication, and management, all of which are central to the study and practice of
environmental health. His specific interests lie in the area of toxic chemicals. He has
published papers on a number of such chemicals and his expertise has been widely
sought as a consultant in risk assessment studies for specific chemicals.
A committed and excellent teacher, within the Department of Environmental
Health Sciences, Professor Chin has taught environmental carcinogenesis, risk
evaluation and management, microbial ecology, cell chemistry and function, and
environmental and occupational toxicology.  He was able to bring a powerful
environmental health practitioner's perspective to these difficult subjects, and he
consistently received high praise from his students.
The Regents salute this outstanding scholar by naming Bruce Chin associate
professor emeritus of environmental health sciences and associate research scientist
emeritus.
Richard L. Christiansen, D.D.S., Ph.D, professor of dentistry and former dean,
School of Dentistry, retired from active faculty status on December 31, 2000.
Dr. Christiansen received his D.D.S. degree from the University of Iowa in 1959,
his M.S.D. degree from Indiana University in 1964, and his Ph.D. degree in physiology
from the University of Minnesota in 1970. From 1970-82, he held a number of
positions at the National Institute of Dental Research, National Institutes of Health,
including program officer of the developmental biology and oral-facial anomalies
program, chief of the craniofacial anomalies program branch, and associate director of
extramural programs. He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan School of
Dentistry in 1982 as dean and professor of dentistry and served as dean until 1987.
During this time, he also served as director of the school's W. K. Kellogg Foundation
Institute for Graduate and Postgraduate Dentistry.
Dr. Christiansen has been an active participant in the department's teaching and
clinical activity in the specialty of orthodontics.  He has served on a number of
departmental, school, and University committees and was director of the School of
Dentistry's postgraduate program. He participated in the University's mentorship program


314




June Meeting, 2001


and served on the governing board of the International Institute and on the Senate
Assembly.
During his tenure as dean, Dr. Christiansen initiated relationships with nine foreign
schools of oral health. He was involved in the establishment of the International Union
of Schools of Oral Health in 1985. He is a member of numerous professional
organizations and is also a member of Omicron Kappa Upsilon and Sigma Xi. In June
2000, Dr. Christiansen was awarded an honorary doctorate degree from Nippon Dental
University, Tokyo, Japan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health science educator by naming
Richard L. Christiansen professor emeritus of dentistry and dean emeritus.
Jane Wilson Coon, D.N.S., R.N., assistant professor of nursing in the School of
Nursing, retired from active faculty status on December 31, 2000, after 14 years of
service to the University of Michigan.
Professor Coon received her B.S.N. degree from the University of Michigan in
1964, her M.S. degree from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1967, and her
D.N.S. degree from the University of California at San Francisco in 1983. She first
joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1967 as a lecturer in the School of Nursing
and was promoted to assistant professor in 1969. From 1970-71, she was assistant to
the dean. From 1971-83, Professor Coon served on the faculty of the University of
Toronto. She returned to the University of Michigan as an assistant professor in 1986.
Professor Coon has been the coordinator of the classes "Client Care Management
in Health Care Systems" and "Professional Nursing Practice" from 1992 until her
retirement. She has also been active on numerous University faculty committees and
student thesis projects. She has made numerous presentations, has done extensive
research on cardiac issues, and has authored many books and journal articles. She
currently has two research projects in progress: "A Surgical Outcomes Study at the
University of Michigan Medical Center" and "Treatment of Early Pressure Ulcers in
Critically Ill Patients," funded by 3M Corporation.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Jane Wilson Coon
assistant professor emerita of nursing.
David E. Crawford, Ph.D., professor of music, retired from active faculty
status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Crawford received his B.A. and M.A. degrees, in 1961 and 1964,
respectively, from the University of Kansas and his Ph.D. degree in 1967 from the
University of Illinois. He joined the University of Michigan School of Music faculty as
an instructor in 1967 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1969, associate
professor in 1971, and professor in 1977. He served as associate dean for undergraduate
studies from 1978-84 and 1987-93 and chair of the Department of Musicology from
1993-99.
Professor Crawford's research areas have mainly involved Renaissance source
studies and Renaissance liturgies, although he has also published in opera, computer
applications for musicology, and American music. In addition to having published 40
musicological articles and reviews, he is the author of Vespers Polyphony at Modena's
Cathedral in the First Half of the Sixteenth Century (1967); Sixteenth-Century
Choirbooks in the Archivio Capitolare at Casale Monferrato (1975); Francesco
Cellavenia, Collected Works (1978); The Anonymous Compendium Musices: Venetiis,
1499-1597 (a critical edition) (1985); and Gaspar de Albertis' Sixteenth-Century


315




June Meeting, 2001


Choirbooks at Bergamo, co-authored with Scott Messing (1994). Of special importance
is his "Renaissance Liturgical Imprints: A Census," a database consisting of more than
13,400 books and one of the first world-wide web applications in musicology. He has
received research fellowships from the American Council of Learned Societies and his
research has been supported by the Gladys Delmas Foundation, the American
Philosophical Society, and the National Endowment for the Humanities.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming David E. Crawford
professor emeritus of music.
Tom A. Croxton, J.D., professor of social work, will retire from active faculty
status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Croxton received his B.A. degree from Miami University in 1953, and
his LL.B., M.S.W., and J.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1958, 1960,
and 1968, respectively. He joined the University of Michigan School of Social Work as
an assistant professor in 1964 and was promoted to associate professor in 1968 and
professor in 1975. He served as acting associate dean from 1976-77 and in 1981 he
took on the additional responsibility of director of admissions, a position he held for
four years.
Professor Croxton's major professional interests involved criminal and juvenile
justice systems; confidentiality, privacy and privileged communications; mental health
law; law and social work; the child, the family, and the law; and social work ethics. His
research focused on law and social work in the practice areas of child welfare, mental
and physical health, education, child custody, and juvenile justice. Recent areas of
interest include the future of the juvenile justice system and social work standards of
practice. The latter involves state and national surveys on clinical social work practices
and beliefs.  He has presented papers on "Protecting the Rights of the Child,"
"Community Related Correctional Programs" (with H. Johnson), "Client Participation
and Client Rights," and "Privileged Communications and the Social Worker." He has
also published in such journals as the Journal of Family Law, Child Welfare, the
Journal of Juvenile Law, Urban Crime and Urban Planning, the Journal of Teaching in
Social Work, and Social Work.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Tom A.
Croxton professor emeritus of social work.
Seyhan N. Ege, Ph.D., professor of chemistry in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
A native of Turkey, Professor Ege received her B.S. degree in 1949 from the
American College for Girls in Istanbul, Turkey, her M.A. degree from Smith College in
1952, and her Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1956. She joined the
University of Michigan faculty as an instructor of chemistry in 1965 and was promoted
to assistant professor in 1967, associate professor in 1970, and professor in 1980. From
1989-92, Professor Ege served as associate chair of the department for curricular
development and faculty affairs. She was designated as an Arthur F. Thurnau Professor
in 1990.
Professor Ege has been the creator, driving force, and leading spirit behind the
chemistry department's new curriculum  initiative.  She is known and respected
internationally as a leader in chemical education for her role in the new curriculum
design and change. Many elements and ideas that were introduced in her book, Organic


316




June Meeting, 2001


Chemistry: Structure & Reactivity, have now been imitated and blended into the
frameworks of other chemistry textbooks.
Professor Ege has been and continues to be a strong advocate for the department's
undergraduate students and for undergraduate learning in general. She has been a
mentor, counselor, and advisor to thousands of students. She made chemistry a lively
activity and motivated students to pursue careers in science. Her combination of
dedication, sincerity, patience, and ability to inspire students has been truly unique.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Seyhan N.
Ege professor emerita of chemistry.
Sidney Fine, Ph.D., professor of history and the Andrew Dickson White
Professor of History in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, will retire
from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Fine received his B.A. degree from Western Reserve University in 1942
and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1944 and 1948,
respectively. He began his career at the University of Michigan as an instructor in 1948
and was promoted to assistant professor in 1951, associate professor in 1955, and
professor in 1959. He was appointed the Andrew Dickson White Distinguished
Professor of History in 1974.
For 53 years, Professor Fine has been an exemplary scholar, teacher, and
colleague. He is an outstanding leader in American labor history and is the foremost
scholar of the social and political history of Michigan. Among his 11 books, which
altogether have won 8 awards, are a 3-volume study of the life and times of Frank
Murphy and accounts of the General Motors sit-down strike of 1936-37 and the Detroit
riots of 1967. He received a Guggenheim Fellowship, was elected president of Labor
Historians, and received 3 honorary degrees. He chaired the Department of History
from 1969-71, served on the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts Executive
Committee from 1960-65, and was a member of many other college and departmental
committees.  Professor Fine received the University of Michigan's Distinguished
Faculty Achievement Award in 1969 and was named the Henry Russel Lecturer for
1984-85.
Professor Fine has always been an extraordinarily dedicated and effective teacher.
The Council for Advancement and Support of Education named him Professor of the
Year for the state of Michigan in 1986, and he received a special tribute from the state
in 1997. He is the only member of the UM faculty to have ever been designated as the
Henry Russel Lecturer as well as being honored by the undergraduates with the Golden
Apple Award for outstanding university teaching.
The Regents salute this distinguished scholar by naming Sidney Fine professor
emeritus of history and the Andrew Dickson White professor emeritus of history.
Charles D. Garvin, Ph.D., professor of social work, will retire from active faculty
status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Garvin received his M.A. (1951) and Ph.D. (1968) degrees in social
work from the University of Chicago. He joined the University of Michigan School of
Social Work as an assistant professor of social work in 1965 and was promoted to
associate professor in 1969 and professor in 1972.
His major interests were in the development of effective group work procedures
and, more recently, on the rehabilitation of individuals with a dual diagnosis of both
mental illness and substance abuse. He has conducted research on how different


317




June Meeting, 2001


societies direct programs to ameliorate ethnic and class conflicts among youth. This
research involved the development and testing of a family intervention for dually
diagnosed individuals who are unmotivated for treatment. He has also had extensive
international experience, having worked with colleagues in Hungary, Poland,
Macedonia, and Croatia.
Professor Garvin has taught an extraordinary range of courses in social work,
including intervention methods with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and
communities as well as courses on human behavior and the social environment and
recently, international social work. He has served as chair of the Interpersonal Practice
Program, Curriculum Committee, Dean's Search Committee, and Strategic Planning
Committee. He has served two terms on the school's executive committee and was the
director of the doctoral program from 1989-96.
Professor Garvin has authored several books, including Social Work in
Contemporary Society, Contemporary Group Work, Interpersonal Practice in Social
Work, and The Work Incentive Experience, which reports a four-year research project on
the Work Incentive Program.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Charles D.
Garvin professor emeritus of social work.
Adon A. Gordus, Ph.D., professor of chemistry in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001, following a
distinguished career as a teacher and a scholar.
Professor Gordus received his B.S. degree in chemistry from the Illinois Institute
of Technology in 1952 and his Ph.D. degree in chemistry from the University of
Wisconsin in 1956. Following a postdoctoral fellowship, he joined the University of
Michigan faculty as an instructor in 1957. He was promoted to assistant professor in
1960, associate professor in 1964, and professor in 1970.
Professor Gordus was noted both for his research in neutron activation analysis,
especially of minerals, art objects, and artifacts of archeological interest, and for his
outstanding teaching and mentoring of undergraduate students. He served as assistant
director of the Honors Program for many years and regularly taught undergraduate
analytical chemistry. He was among the first to introduce the use of personal computers
to students and developed a set of applications for the exploration of statistical treatment
of analytical data in ordinary spreadsheets. He also authored a popular textbook on
quantitative analysis for the Schaum's Outline series.
For his contributions to the undergraduate curriculum and his devotion to
undergraduate teaching and mentoring, Professor Gordus received the Amoco Good
Teaching Award.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Adon A.
Gordus professor emeritus of chemistry.
Robert D. Hanson, Ph.D., professor of civil engineering in the Department of
Civil and Environmental Engineering, College of Engineering, retired from active
faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Hanson received his B.S. and M.S. degrees from the University of
Minnesota in 1957 and 1958, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from the California
Institute of Technology in 1965. Following a year at the University of California at
Davis, he joined the University of Michigan faculty as an assistant professor in 1966.


318




June Meeting, 2001


He was promoted to associate professor in 1969 and professor in 1974 and served as
chair of the Department of Civil Engineering from 1976-84.
Professor Hanson's research focused on earthquake response of structures and
structural systems. He authored more than 100 refereed publications and was chair or
co-chair of 23 Ph.D. dissertation committees. In 1984, he was elected to the National
Academy of Engineering (NAE) and from January 1989 through December 1990 he
served as program director of the Division of Biological and Critical Engineering
Systems in the Engineering Directorate of the National Science Foundation (NSF).
From 1994-2000, Professor Hanson was a senior earthquake engineer for the Federal
Emergency Management Agency under an intergovernmental personnel agreement. He
chaired 3 major committees of the American Society of Civil Engineers, was president
of the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute from 1989-91, and was a member of
the American Concrete Institute, American Society of Engineering Education, and
Seismological Society of America. In 1986, the College of Engineering awarded
Professor Hanson its prestigious Steven S. Atwood Excellence in Engineering Award.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for dedicated service by
naming Robert D. Hanson professor emeritus of civil engineering.
Elton D. Higgs, Ph.D., professor of English language and literature in the College
of Arts, Sciences, and Letters at the University of Michigan-Dearborn, retired from
active faculty status on April 30, 2001.
Professor Higgs received his B.A. degree from Abilene Christian College in 1961
and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Pittsburgh in 1963 and 1965,
respectively. He joined the University of Michigan-Dearborn faculty as an assistant
professor of English in 1965 and was promoted to associate professor in 1970 and
professor in 1974.
Professor Higgs, whose major area of scholarship is Middle English literature, has
published a number of scholarly articles and book reviews on Chaucer, Langland,
Shakespeare, and Milton. He also co-authored a volume of the Index of Middle English
Prose in 1988 and is the author of A Gift Renewed: The First 25 Years of the University
of Michigan-Dearborn, 1959-1984.
Within the College of Arts, Sciences, and Letters, Professor Higgs served as acting
dean from 1973-74, associate dean from 1974-76, director of graduate studies from
1976-80, and as a member of the CASL executive committee. Most recently, he served
as director of the College of Arts, Sciences, and Letters' Master of Liberal Studies
Program (1997-present). He developed the core curriculum for the first freshman class
of the University of Michigan-Dearborn. Professor Higgs also chaired the University of
Michigan-Dearborn NCA self-study from 1982-84 and co-chaired the self-study again
from 1992-94.
The Regents salute this dedicated and accomplished teacher and scholar by naming
Elton D. Higgs professor emeritus of English language and literature.
Peggie J. Hollingsworth, Ph.D., assistant research scientist, completed her faculty
appointment on May 31, 1999, after a successful career as a researcher and educator.
Dr. Hollingsworth received her B.S. degree in biology and chemistry from the
University of Toledo in 1959, her M.A. degree in molecular biology from Bowling
Green State University in 1970, and her Ph.D. degree in toxicology from the University
of Michigan in 1982. She joined the University of Michigan faculty as a research
investigator in the Department of Pharmacology in 1982 and was promoted to assistant


319




June Meeting, 2001


research scientist in 1985. From 1983-99, she also served as assistant research scientist
in the Toxicology Research Labs in the School of Public Health. During 1992 and
1994, Dr. Hollingsworth was a visiting scientist at Hokkaido University Medical School
in Sapporo, Japan.
Dr. Hollingsworth has an outstanding service record, both within the University
community and at the national level. She served as chair of SACUA in the 1990-91
academic year and during that time, she was also president of Sigma Xi. In recognition
of her contributions, she was awarded the Academic Women's Caucus Sarah Goddard
Power Award in 1990, the Association of Black Professionals and Administrators
Appreciation Award in 1992, and the Distinguished Faculty Governance Award in
1994.
The Regents now salute this distinguished researcher for her dedicated service by
naming Peggie J. Hollingsworth assistant research scientist emerita.
Nancy M. Houk, Ph.D., research scientist in the Department of Astronomy,
retired from active faculty status on March 31, 2001.
Dr. Houk received her B.S. degree from the University of Michigan in 1962, her
M.S. degree from Case Institute of Technology in 1964, and her Ph.D. degree from Case
Western Reserve University in 1967. From 1967-70, she held postgraduate positions at
Case Western Reserve University and at the Kapteyn Laboratory in Groningen, The
Netherlands.  Following a brief tour as acting director of the Maria Mitchell
Observatory in Nantucket, Massachusetts, she joined the astronomy department at
Michigan as a research associate in December of 1970. She was promoted to assistant
research scientist in 1973, associate research scientist in 1977, and research scientist in
1985.
Dr. Houk conceived and carried out the monumental task of classifying some two
hundred thousand stars from the Henry Draper Catalogue. These classifications were
made on the modern two-dimensional system which provides a measure of both the
surface temperature of a star and its intrinsic luminosity.  This work enjoyed
international acclaim and received more than two million dollars in funding from the
National Science Foundation for more than three decades. Well over one hundred
graduate and undergraduate students received an introduction to research as part of Dr.
Houk's team, and several have gone on to professional careers in astronomy. Her work
has been published in professional journals and presented at national and international
meetings. Dr. Houk will continue to work on the project after her retirement.
In addition to astronomical societies, Dr. Houk is a member of the American
Association for the Advancement of Religion in an Age of Science. She has also been
active in the University of Michigan Choral Union and in the Chancel Choir of the First
Presbyterian Church of Ann Arbor. She remains a keen supporter of the University of
Michigan and Detroit sports teams. As an opera fan she travels regularly to Chicago,
Detroit, and New York.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Nancy M. Houk research
scientist emerita.
John W. Konnak, M.D., professor of surgery, will retire from active faculty
status on June 30, 2001, after a most productive career as a physician, surgeon, teacher,
and researcher.
A native of Wisconsin, Dr. Konnak received his B.S. and M.D. degrees, in 1959
and 1962, respectively, from the University of Wisconsin. He interned at Philadelphia


320




June Meeting, 2001


General Hospital from 1962-63. His surgery residency was completed at Harbor
General Hospital in Torrance, California, in 1965-66. He then entered the Urology
Residency Program at the University of Michigan in 1966 and completed his residency
training in 1969. He was appointed to the faculty in 1969 as an instructor and was
promoted to assistant professor in 1971, associate professor in 1974, and professor in
1982.
Dr. Konnak's association with the University of Michigan began during the days of
Dr. Reed Nesbit, when Michigan's urology program was establishing its national
preeminence. During his career, he trained numerous residents who are now scattered
throughout the country in various academic and private practices. He was a recipient of
the Silver Cystoscope Award and Outstanding Achievement Award for his contribution
to resident education and growth of the Section of Urology. His many contributions to
the field of urology include urologic oncology and renal transplantation. Despite his
retirement, he will continue to perform living donor nephrectomies with the Medical
Center transplant team.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physician, surgeon, and teacher for his
dedicated service by naming John W. Konnak professor emeritus of surgery.
Samuel Krimm, Ph.D., professor of physics in the College of Literature, Science,
and the Arts, professor of macromolecular science and engineering in the College of
Engineering, and research scientist in the Biophysics Research Division, retired from
active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Krimm received his B.S. degree from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn
in 1947 and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Princeton University in 1949 and 1950,
respectively. He joined the University of Michigan faculty as an instructor in 1952 and
was promoted to assistant professor in 1954, associate professor in 1958, and professor
in 1963. He served as associate dean for research and facilities, College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, from 1972-75, chair of the Biophysics Research Division from
1976-86, and director of the Program in Protein Structure and Design from 1986-94.
A prolific researcher, Professor Krimm has over 280 publications. He pioneered
the use of vibrational spectroscopy methods and produced a benchmark series of papers
on synthetic and natural macromolecules. He proposed and implemented the isotopic
substitution technique for defining the state of folded polymer chains, which played a
major role in clarifying our concepts of the structure of crystalline polymers and the
structural basis of the infrared and Raman spectra of proteins. His recent work focuses
on the development of accurate potential energy functions for polymers and proteins.
Professor Krimm's honors include the High Polymer Physics Prize (1977) from the
American Physical Society and the University of Michigan's Distinguished Faculty
Achievement Award (1986). He is a fellow of the American Physical Society and the
American Association for the Advancement of Science and was a senior fellow in the
UM Society of Fellows (1971-76). In 1983, he was awarded the Humboldt Prize,
Germany's highest research award for senior U.S. scientists and scholars in all
disciplines.
The Regents now salute this distinguished teacher and scholar by naming Samuel
Krimm professor emeritus of physics, professor emeritus of macromolecular science
and engineering, and research scientist emeritus.
Robert L. Macdonald, M.D., Ph.D., professor of neurology, the Russell N.
DeJong Professor of Neurology, and professor of physiology, will retire from active


321




June Meeting, 2001


faculty status on June 30, 2001, after a most productive career as a teacher, clinician,
and basic investigator.
A native of Michigan, Dr. Macdonald received his B.S. degree from the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1966 and his Ph.D. and M.D. degrees from the
University of Virginia in 1969 and 1973, respectively. He served his internship and
residency at the University of Virginia from 1974-77. He was a research assistant
professor of neurology at the University of Virginia and an investigator at the National
Institutes of Health from 1976-78. He joined the University of Michigan faculty as
associate professor of neurology in 1978. He was promoted to professor of neurology in
1981, was appointed professor of physiology in 1982, and was installed as the first
Russell N. DeJong Professor of Neurology in 1995. He has contributed strength and
vitality to both instructional and research programs of the Department of Neurology.
Dr. Macdonald's publication record includes 165 refereed journal articles and 52
book chapters. He received the S. Weir Mitchell Award (1978) and the Cotzias Award
(1996) from the American Academy of Neurology; the latter is the highest research
award given by the AAN. He has received the Epilepsy Research Award of the
American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (1986). He has
served as president of the American Epilepsy Society and gave its Lennox Lecture in
1994. Dr. Macdonald gave the University of Michigan Biomedical Research Council
Distinguished Lecture in 1998. He has made major contributions to the understanding
of 1) the biophysical and pharmacological properties, structure, and functional assembly
of the y-aminobutyric acid Type A (GABAA) receptor channel, 2) the mechanisms of
action of a wide variety of antiepileptic drugs that are used to treat patients with epilepsy,
and 3) the basis for the prolonged seizures of status epilepticus.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physician-scientist for his dedicated
service by naming Robert L. Macdonald professor emeritus of neurology, the Russell N.
DeJong Professor Emeritus of Neurology, and professor emeritus of physiology.
William M. Marsh, professor of physical geography at the University of
Michigan-Flint and adjunct professor of natural resources in the School of Natural
Resources and Environment, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Marsh received his A.B. degree from Central Michigan University in
1964 and his A.M. degree from the University of Missouri in 1965. He joined the
faculty of the University of Michigan-Flint in 1970 as a lecturer in the Department of
Earth and Resource Science. He was promoted to instructor in 1971, assistant professor
in 1975, associate professor in 1979, and professor in 1990. He also served as
department chair for more than 25 years.
Professor Marsh was active in teaching and research on both the Flint and Ann Arbor
campuses. His work involved three disciplines: geomorphology, landscape architecture,
and environmental planning, and his contributions at the point where these three fields
overlap have made a vital difference in professional practice in landscape architecture.
He frequently lectured in landscape architecture, architecture, and urban planning on the
Ann Arbor campus. Professor Marsh was a gifted teacher who brought a wonderful
artistic talent to blackboard illustrations that left lasting impressions on students and
colleagues.
Professor Marsh has been honored with the David M. French Distinguished
Professorship (1994-96), the University of Michigan-Flint Faculty Scholarly Achievement
Award (1990-91), and the Michigan Association of Governing Boards of Colleges and


322




June Meeting, 2001


Universities Distinguished Faculty Award (1995). He serves on the Canadian Society of
Landscape Architecture National Accreditation Board and the Editorial Advisory Board of
the Landscape and Urban Planning Journal. He is an honorary member of the Michigan
Society of Landscape Architecture and was a great master in landscape architecture at
Texas A&M University in 1985 and 1986. He has lectured widely throughout North
America, has published six books, and is widely recognized as a leader in the field of
landscape planning.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming William M. Marsh professor emeritus of physical geography.
Gene M. Schramm, Ph.D., professor of Semitics in the Department of Near
Eastern Studies, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001, after 36 years of
distinguished service.
Professor Schramm received his B.A. and M.A. degrees from the University of
California at Berkeley in 1948 and 1950, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from
Dropsie College, Philadelphia, in 1956. He began his academic career at the University
of California at Berkeley as an assistant professor in 1959. He joined the University of
Michigan faculty as an associate professor of  Semitics and linguistics in the
Department of Near Eastern Studies in 1965 and was promoted to professor in 1971.
Professor Schramm is one of the leading Semitists and linguistic theorists who
made striking discoveries in comparative Semitic phonology, Hebrew and Arabic verbal
syntax and semantics, dialect geography, and linguistic-literary analysis of Hebrew. As
his colleague Prof  eset McCarus once observed, "Gene Schramm is a superb
linguist, foremost in the areas of comparative-historical linguistics and transformational
theory." Professor Schramm was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship for 1964-65 and
served as treasurer of the American Oriental Society from 1989-91. His numerous
professional affiliations include the American Oriental Society, the Linguistic Group at
Berkeley, the Linguistic Society of America, the International Linguistic Society of New
York, the Judaic Studies Committee, and the Society for Biblical Literature.
Professor Schramm was a devoted and much loved teacher. He taught classes in
Jewish Civilizations, Intermediate Hebrew, Medieval Hebrew Literature, Tannaitic
Literature, Great Books, Comparative Semitic Linguistics, and Structure of Hebrew.
His colleague Professor Ralph Williams aptly observed, "Gene Schramm is a man of
great learning, great good will, and good spirit."
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Gene M. Schramm
professor emeritus of Semitics.
James H. Sherman, Ph.D., associate professor of physiology, retired from active
faculty status on December 31, 2000, after a long and productive career as a teacher and
researcher.
A native of Detroit, Professor Sherman received his B.S. degree from the
University of Michigan in 1957 and his Ph.D. degree from Cornell University in 1963.
He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan as an instructor in physiology in
1964 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1966 and associate professor in 1971.
From 1972-77, he served as assistant director of the Office of Allied Health Education
in the Department of Postgraduate Medicine.
Professor Sherman has made major contributions as an educator within the Medical
School. For many years, he directed and taught "Introductory Human Physiology," a
course taken by a variety of undergraduates.  He taught muscle, respiratory, and


323




June Meeting, 2001


gastrointestinal physiology to both medical and graduate students and, from 1999-2000,
served as director of the first year medical physiology course. Professor Sherman served
on many committees involved in planning and administering the preclinical medical
curriculum and was well-known for his efforts in helping graduate students to become
good teachers. His research focused on amino acid transport and he served on a number
of thesis committees and fostered the hypothesis-testing approach to research in a
generation of Ph.D. students. Professor Sherman is co-author with Drs. A. Vander and
D. Luciano of the widely-used textbook, Human Physiology: The Mechanisms of Body
Function, which has evolved through eight editions over thirty years and is one of the
most widely used texts in its field.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health science educator for his dedicated
service by naming James H. Sherman associate professor emeritus of physiology.
Thomas C. Shope, M.D., associate professor of pediatrics and communicable
diseases in the Medical School, will retire from active faculty status on June 30, 2001.
Dr. Shope received his B.A. degree from the State University of Iowa in 1960 and
his M.D. degree from Cornell University Medical School in 1964 and was an intern and
resident at the University of Minnesota University Hospitals from 1964-67. From
1967-69, he was an epidemiologist at the National Centers for Disease Control, and
from 1969-73, he was a fellow in Pediatric Infectious Diseases and then an instructor at
Yale University School of Medicine. From 1973-82, he was a faculty member at Wayne
State University. Dr. Shope joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1982 as
associate professor of pediatrics in the Departments of Pediatrics and Communicable
Diseases and Pathology and from 1982-95 was also associate professor of epidemiology
in the School of Public Health.
Dr. Shope's research has centered on a variety of aspects of infection with human
viruses and, more recently, on medical student education. His extensive record as an
administrator includes service as director of the Pediatric Infectious Diseases Service,
director of the Pediatric Bacteriology Laboratory and the Virology Diagnostic
Laboratory, medical director of the Infectious Diseases and Isolation Unit at C. S. Mott
Children's Hospital, director of the House Officer Program in the Department of
Pediatrics, associate dean for academic programs and associate dean for student
programs at the Medical School, and director of Clinical and Educational Programs in
Primary Care in the Department of Pediatrics.
Dr. Shope has had an active clinical practice in pediatric infectious diseases in the
Outpatient Consultation Clinic and in the Consultation Service at C. S. Mott Children's
Hospital. He has taught medical students, pediatric residents, and infectious diseases
fellows and has participated in departmental seminars, lectures, and Medical School
courses. He has devoted considerable effort to curriculum design in Pediatric Primary
Care and in conducting faculty development seminars in medical education.
The Regents salute this distinguished and productive faculty member by naming
Thomas C. Shope associate professor emeritus of pediatrics and communicable
diseases.
James A. Standifer, Ph.D., professor of music (music education), School of
Music, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Standifer received his B.A. and M.A. degrees from Fisk University in
1957 and 1958, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from Case Western Reserve
University in 1968. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1970 as associate


324




June Meeting, 2001


professor in the School of Music and lecturer in the School of Education; he was
promoted to professor of music in 1973. He was chair of the Department of Music
Education from 1976-79 and has served as the director of the Eva Jessye Collection of
Afro-American Music since 1980.
A specialist in secondary school general music and urban and multicultural
music education, Professor Standifer is active internationally as a consultant and
lecturer. He directed the Oral History Video Archive/Black American Musicians at the
Center for African American and African Studies and has produced TV programs about
music education and American music and musicians for PBS. He was a writer and
senior advisor for the series "From Jumpstreet: A Story of Black Music;" music
consultant on a documentary about Moms Mabley; and consultant on a Shedd
Productions documentary using multicultural music titled "Why Is Music Music?"
Professor Standifer has conducted research on the cultures of China, Korea,
Libya, Ghana, and South Africa. He is co-author of several books, including the
secondary school vocal music series Sound Beat and Feeling; Sound, Shape and
Symbol; African and Afro-American Materials for The Music Educator; and Methods
and Perspectives in Urban Music Education. He is a reader/evaluator for the Minorities
Fellowship Program of the Ford Foundation, the National Research Council, and the
U.S. Department of Education's Jacob Javits Fellowship Program. His work has been
supported by the NEA, NEH, National Academy of Sciences, Ford Foundation, Dorothy
and DuBose Hayward Memorial Fund, Ira and Leonora Gershwin Foundation, the
George Gershwin Foundation, and the National Black TV Programming Consortium.
He recently produced an award-winning documentary for PBS, "Porgy and Bess: An
American Voice," which aired nationally and is being distributed worldwide.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming James A. Standifer
professor emeritus of music (music education).
Joan S. Stark, Ed.D., professor of education and former dean, School of
Education, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001, after 23 years of
service to the University of Michigan.
Professor Stark received her B.S. degree from Syracuse University in 1957, her
M.A. degree from Teachers College, Columbia University in 1960, and her Ed.D.
degree from the State University of New York at Albany in 1971. Following
employment as a high school teacher, college instructor, and administrator at Goucher
College (1970-74) and Syracuse University (1974-78), Professor Stark joined the
University of Michigan School of Education in 1978 as dean and professor. She served
as dean until 1983.
A leading authority on post secondary curriculum and teaching, Professor Stark
directed the federally-funded National Center for Research to Improve Post Secondary
Teaching and Learning from 1986-91. She has done extensive research and published
widely on issues related to college curriculum, curriculum leadership, and teaching and
learning in higher education. Her research is cited frequently and is used as a
conceptual framework for dissertations and improvement practice throughout the U.S.,
Europe, and Australia. She was editor of the Review of Higher Education from
1991-96. She has served as curriculum consultant to educational programs in many
professional fields such as nursing, accounting, medicine, and journalism.
Professor Stark has received a number of national awards, including the Exemplary
Research Award from the American Educational Research Association; the Research


325




June Meeting, 2001


Achievement Award, Distinguished Service Award, and most recently, the Howard
Bowen Distinguished Career Award from the Association for the Study of Higher
Education; and the Suslow Career Research Award and Distinguished Membership
Award from the Association for Institutional Research. Her teaching has consistently
received praise from students and her mentorship is highly valued by the graduate
students with whom she works.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Joan S. Stark professor
emerita of education and dean emerita.
Harold W. Stevenson, Ph.D., professor of psychology in the College of
Literature, Science, and the Arts and fellow in the Center for Human Growth and
Development, will retire from active faculty status on June 30, 2001.
Professor Stevenson received his B.A. degree from the University of Colorado in
1947 and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Stanford University in 1948 and 1951,
respectively. He served on the faculty of the University of Texas until 1959, when he
became director of the Institute of Child Development at the University of Minnesota.
In 1971, he came to Michigan as a fellow in the Center for Human Growth and
Development and professor in the Department of Psychology.
Early in his career, Professor Stevenson and a handful of other researchers defined
and established the field of children's learning. He initiated much of the basic research
on the effects of tangible and social rewards on children's learning, children's learning
of central versus incidental content, the influence of anxiety and failure on children's
learning, and their learning from filmed or televised displays. At Michigan, Professor
Stevenson began focusing on cognition, learning, and achievement in schools,
comparing school achievement across a variety of cultures, especially the U.S., China,
and Japan. Professor Stevenson elegantly overcame the monumental obstacles to
collecting the needed culturally comparable data essential to comparing learning and
achievement across contrasting cultural practices in order to fully understand how
humans develop adult abilities. His persuasive articulation of his findings changed the
face of the national discussion about schools and achievement. His research efforts
stand as a model of scientific rigor coupled with practical implications and societal
impact.
Professor Stevenson has received numerous honors and awards, including
membership in the National Academy of Education; the APA Distinguished Scientific
Award for the Applications of Psychology; and the James McKeen Cattell Fellow
Award in Applied Psychology. Equally impressive are the unusually productive records
of the more than 40 Ph.D. students he has mentored into illustrious careers of their own.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Harold W. Stevenson
professor emeritus of psychology and fellow emeritus in the Center for Human Growth
and Development.
Benjamin A. Stolz, Ph.D., professor of Slavic languages and literatures, will retire
from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Stolz received his A.B. degree in 1955 from the University of Michigan
and his A.M. and Ph.D. degrees in 1957 and 1965, respectively, from Harvard
University. He joined the University of Michigan faculty as an assistant professor in
1964 and was promoted to associate professor in 1969 and professor in 1973.
During his thirty-seven years on the Michigan faculty, Professor Stolz has traveled
the entire academic path-including his extended and exceptional service as department


326




June Meeting, 2001


chair. His primary academic area is Slavic linguistics, with particular emphasis on
South Slavic languages and cultures. Professor Stolz's research interests and resulting
publications are broad, ranging from the formation of South Slavic literary languages to
South Slavic oral folklore (including the epic). A well-received translation and critical
edition of the sixteenth-century manuscript Konstantin Mihailovic Turkish Chronicle is
just one of his many remarkable South Slavic projects. His teaching was exemplary,
ranging from a backbone course in Old Church Slavic to courses on South Slavic
folklore and sociolinguistics.
Professor Stolz actively promoted cultural contacts with Eastern Europe and has
become a well-respected academic anchor for a number of Slavists from the area,
especially from the former Yugoslavia. A frequent visitor to this part of Eastern
Europe, he has a profound understanding of its languages and cultures. He has also
been active in forming academic links with Russia. In the late 1980s, when it suddenly
became possible for Russian intellectuals to travel abroad for the first time, he
succeeded in bringing a number of renowned Russian linguists to the University. Last
but not least, Professor Stolz's involvement in the American career of the Russian poet
and Nobel Laureate Joseph Brodsky, and his elegant tribute to Brodsky in the form of a
scholarly symposium in 1996, testify to the depth of his sympathy and understanding
and his abilities in uniting diverse interests in support of a good cause.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Benjamin A. Stolz
professor emeritus of Slavic languages and literatures.
Thomas F. Storer, Ph.D., professor of mathematics in the College of Literature,
Science and Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Storer received his B.A. degree from the University of California at Los
Angeles in 1959 and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Southern
California in 1962 and 1964, respectively. He joined the University of Michigan faculty
as a T. H. Hildebrandt Research Instructor in 1965, and was promoted to assistant
professor in 1967, associate professor in 1970, and professor in 1979.
Professor Storer's research area was primarily in combinatorics, more specifically
cyclotomy, and his monograph "Cyclotomy and Difference Sets" (1967) became a
standard reference. He also conducted research in modeling of long-term memory and
recognition and directed the thesis work of eight doctoral students. Professor Storer was
an outstanding teacher, especially of honors students. A firm believer that students will
respond to challenges, his courses were among the most rigorous, but his distinctive
teaching style, coupled with great intellectual excitement, drew students to his classes
and led them to take additional courses from him. In recognition of his teaching skills,
he was awarded the Amoco Foundation Good Teaching Award in 1985. Professor
Storer also had a great impact on students in his role as a freshman-sophomore
counselor for the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts Honors Program, a
position he held for 32 years. It was in that role where his integrity, sensitivity,
patience, and empathy for students enabled him not only to guide them academically,
but also to help them become well-rounded individuals.
Professor Storer is very proud of his Native American ancestry and culture. For
many years, he was the principle faculty spokesman for Native Americans and he
counseled most of the Native American students. Among other endeavors, he taught the
Ojibwa language, worked on an Ojibwa dictionary, and wrote about string figures.


327




June Meeting, 2001


The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Thomas F. Storer professor
emeritus of mathematics.
Charles Witke, Ph.D., professor of Greek and Latin in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001.
Professor Witke received his B.A. degree from the University of California at Los
Angeles in 1953 and his A.M. and Ph.D. degrees from Harvard University in 1957 and
1962, respectively.  He began his career as assistant professor of classics at the
University of Chicago in 1962. From there, he moved to the University of California at
Berkeley, where he was assistant professor (1963-68), associate professor (1968-70),
and chair of the Committee on Mediaeval Studies (1964-70). He served as professor of
classics and comparative literature at the State University of New York at Binghamton
in 1970 and joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1971 as professor of classical
studies and director of the Program in Comparative Literature. He served as associate
dean, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts from 1971-74 and was a member of
the college's executive committee from 1975-78.
Professor Witke is well known for his work on Latin literature, in which he has
published extensively. The books for which he is sure to be remembered are his fine
studies of the Roman satirists: Lucilius, Horace, and Juvenal. He focused much of his
later research on texts of the Middle Ages and Renaissance, where his publications
cover a broad range including Latin paleography, Erasmus, theology, liturgy, and the
history of the Western Christian church. He has written four books and numerous
articles and recently completed a translation of Erasmus' Hyperapistes.
Following his interests in comparative literature and church history, Professor
Witke has traveled widely. As a student, he held a Fulbright Fellowship to Italy and
was awarded the Rome Prize in Classics by the American Academy in Rome (1960-62).
He has returned to the academy often over the years as a visiting scholar and in 1997
was appointed resident in classics. He has held grants from various universities and
from the National Endowment for the Humanities.
The Regents salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Charles Witke
professor emeritus of Greek and Latin.
Lung Chiang Wu, Ph.D., associate professor of computer science at the
University of Michigan-Flint, retired from active faculty status on December 31, 2000.
Professor Wu obtained his B.Sc. degree from the Cheng Kung University, Taiwan
in 1962, his M.S. degree from Kansas State University in 1965, his M.S. degree from
the University of Michigan in 1972, and his Ph.D. degree in industrial and operations
engineering from the University of Michigan in 1980. He worked at AC Spark Plug,
General Motors Corporation, and the State of Michigan before joining the University of
Michigan-Flint faculty as an associate professor of computer science in 1981. He
served as chair of the department from 1986-89 and again from 1998-99.
Professor Wu's area of expertise is operations research, and he is a recognized
expert in using operations research models to model manufacturing operations. Early in
his career, he described the use of a mixed integer programming model to handle the
purchase of a platinum catalyst during a fuel crisis when corporations were locked into
long-term contracts. Another publication involves using operations research modeling
to establish optimal buffers of parts between operations on a paced assembly line.
Professor Wu's work is critical to "real world" manufacturing and industrial operations
and is germinal in its field. It resulted in significant cost savings for his employer and


328




June Meeting, 2001


was done in the era of punch cards and Fortran. Later publications focused on assembly
line operation, product changeover, and strategic planning.
His teaching expertise lies in the areas of data structures, simulation and modeling,
database, and artificial intelligence.  Combining his industrial experiences with
classroom situations, he developed courses with "real world" implications and
applications.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his dedicated
service by naming Lung Chiang Wu associate professor emeritus of computer science.
Mayer N. Zald, Ph.D., professor of sociology in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, professor of social work in the School of Social Work, and
professor of business administration in the School of Business Administration, will
retire from active faculty status on May 31, 2001, following a long and distinguished
career as a teacher and researcher.
A native of the Detroit area, Professor Zald received his B.A. degree from the
University of Michigan in 1953, his M.A. degree from the University of Hawaii in 1955,
and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1961. He served on the
faculties of the University of Chicago (1960-64) and Vanderbilt University (1964-77)
before joining the University of Michigan as professor of sociology and professor of
social work in 1977. Professor Zald served as chair of the sociology department from
1981-86 and again from 1990-92. He received the additional appointment as professor
of business administration in 1989.
A superb and highly original researcher, Professor Zald is the author or editor of
some 20 books and edited collections and nearly 80 articles, book chapters, and review
essays. His work spans the fields of organizational studies, collective behavior, and
social theory, and he has made lasting and distinguished contributions in each area. His
research accomplishments have garnered numerous awards and prizes, including
election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and his selection last year as the
Distinguished Senior Faculty Lecturer in the College of Literature, Science, and the
Arts.
Professor Zald is a committed and caring instructor who has exposed generations of
undergraduates to the joys of intellectual inquiry. His warm and supportive style,
coupled with his probing analytical mind, have won over countless graduate students and
colleagues alike.  Professor Zald is renowned and revered for his generosity in
contributing to the work of students, other scholars, and the wider intellectual
communities of which he remains such a vital part.
The Regents now salute this distinguished and multi-talented scholar, teacher, and
colleague by naming Mayer N. Zald professor emeritus of sociology, professor emeritus
of social work, and professor emeritus of business administration.
Memorials. No deaths of active faculty members were reported this month.
Degrees. There were no actions with respect to degrees this month.
Approval of Consent Agenda. On a motion by Regent Horning, seconded by
Regent McGowan, the Regents unanimously approved the Consent Agenda.

License Agreement between the University of Michigan and Rebus Inc.
On a motion by Regent Brandon, seconded by Regent Maynard, the Regents
unanimously approved a license agreement between the University of Michigan and
Rebus Inc. for the technology, "The Ounce of Prevention Scale." Because Samuel
Meisels is both a University of Michigan employee and an owner of Rebus Inc., this
agreement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following
information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and Rebus Inc., a company
owned by Samuel Meisels.
2.   Contract terms include:
Exclusive right to create derivative works, market, distribute and otherwise
commercialize the Scale as it exists at the time the agreement is executed.
The University retains the right to grant rights to sponsors as required by existing
contracts.
The University retains ownership of the Scale and the rights to create derivative works
and to use, reproduce, and publicly display it for the University's own internal use.
The licensee will need to request an amendment that must be reviewed for conflict of
interest if it wishes to have rights to any further work done on the Scale at the
University. This amendment may involve an increase in royalties for the additional
enhancements.
Royalties are a license fee of $1,000 due within 30 days and each year thereafter, plus
20% on gross sublicensing revenue.
Milestones include having a product available and offered for sale by June 3, 2003, and
at least one sale made by June 30, 2004. The University has the option of terminating
the agreement if milestones are not met.
Rebus must maintain product liability coverage and comply with the standard terms the
University requires to manage the liability associated with commercialization.
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University employees
is obligated under the agreement.
3.   The pecuniary interest of Samuel Meisels arises from his ownership in Rebus Inc.

commercialize the technology, "Ras Mutants Control Oncogenic Transformation."
Because Dr. Kun-Liang Guan is both a University of Michigan employee and owner of
Oncolmmune Ltd., this agreement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest
Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the Regents of the University of Michigan and
Oncolmmune Ltd.
2.   Contract terms:


331




June Meeting, 2001


The contract to be completed between the University of Michigan and OncoImmune
Ltd. consists of a license option agreement to be executed by authorized
representatives of the parties.
The license option grants to Oncolmmune Ltd., for TMO File #17669: an option for an
exclusive, worldwide license, including the right to sublicense, to make, have made,
import, use, market, or offer for sale and sell products incorporating the technology.
Should the option be exercised by Oncolmmune Ltd., any license negotiated by the
Parties will include at least the following:
* The University will receive reimbursement for all patent costs.
* The University will receive payment of a running royalty.
* The University will receive milestone payments, or other consideration if
appropriate.
* The University will receive an equity position in the company.
* Oncolmmune will assume diligence requirements for commercializing the
Michigan Intellectual Property.
* Oncolmmune will agree to indemnification and other reasonable and customary
terms in a license agreement, all in conformity with University policy.
The term of this license option agreement is for one year and is renewable for an
additional year, should Oncolmmune meet certain guidelines.
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under the agreement.
3.   Dr. Kun-Liang Guan's pecuniary interest arises from his ownership in Oncolmmune
Ltd. He has waived any personal participation in the sharing of royalties received by
the University from the company.

thereafter during the term of the agreement.
Term of the agreement is for the life of the patent.

Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan and

TheraSonics, Inc. ("TheraSonics") to practice and commercialize 11 inventions identified
as File Nos. 558, 559, 576, 1103, 1218/1326, 1251, 1266, 1328, 1329, 1336, and 1576.
Because Charles A. Cain, Matthew O'Donnell, and S. Adam Strickberger are all
University of Michigan employees who also hold equity interests in TheraSonics, this
agreement falls under the State of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following
information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and TheraSonics.
2.   Contract Terms include:
Exclusive right to practice and commercialize the technology, subject to certain rights
reserved by the University to practice it for research and educational purposes, with
right to grant sub-licenses.
A license issue fee of $120,000 will be applied to reimburse patent expenses and/or
applied against royalties.
Royalties to the University of 3.5% of net sales of products sold by TheraSonics.
Royalties to the University of 25% of total of gross sublicensing revenues received by
TheraSonics.
Specified milestones will be met in order to maintain the rights granted by the license.
All remaining current and future U.S. and foreign patent costs will be paid by the
licensee.
Term of the agreement is for the life of the patents.
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, is obligated under this agreement.
3.   Drs. Cain, O'Donnell, and Strickberger's pecuniary interests arise from their respective
ownership interests in TheraSonics. They have waived any personal participation in
the sharing of royalties received by the University from the company.
